speaker: Linda
text: Mm, we are. I couldn’t possibly ask for a better brother…

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: I’m going to Dozel, Lord Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: Your father was Lord Lex, correct? I’m sure the people of Dozel eagerly await your return, Lex’s son.

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: The likes of Langbalt and Dannan have tormented the people and stained House Dozel’s good name for too long. Now that my father is gone, it falls to me to heal the state’s wounds.

speaker: Seliph
text: Mm. I entrust Dozel’s welfare to you. I pray you’ll be able to lend me your might in the years to come.

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Yes, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Lover
text: Lex’s son, still chatting? C’mon, we should be hurrying!

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Lover? What do you mean?

speaker: Lover
text: Nothing’ll be a sadder sight than having to walk into Dozel while you’re still here. C’mon, you’ll thank me later!

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Heh, I suppose you’re right…

speaker: Lover
text: Still busy chatting, Lex’s son? C’mon, we should be going already!

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Lover? What do you mean?

speaker: Lover
text: Is anything quite as sad as going home alone? I guess you should be thanking me for keeping your arm occupied!

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Heh, I suppose you’re right…

speaker: Lover
text: Are you still chatting, Lex’s son? Shouldn’t we make haste for Dozel?

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Lover? What do you mean?

speaker: Lover
text: I’ll be going with you. I’d be too worried if I wasn’t with you…

speaker: Lex’S Son
text: Ah, right… Thank you, Lover.

speaker: Lex’S Daughter
text: I’m going to Dozel too, Lord Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: You as well Lex’s daughter? I see… You’re welcome to come by Belhalla once in a while for a visit.

speaker: Lex’S Daughter
text: Thank you, sir. I’ll take you up on that offer once Dozel is back to normal.

speaker: Seliph
text: Take care of yourself, Lex’s daughter.

speaker: Lex’S Daughter
text: And you as well, Lord Seliph…

speaker: Johan
text: My liege! I owe you a debt among debts.

speaker: Seliph
text: I leave Dozel’s care to you, Lord Johan.

speaker: Johan
text: Home shall hold only pain for me, yet return I must if I am to absolve my kin’s sins. I know yet not if my people could ever forgive me.

speaker: Seliph
text: This war could never have been won if not for your strength, Johan. Your legacy is one of kindness. People everywhere know this well.

speaker: Johan
text: Your words honor me, my liege. I can only pray you shall someday forgive House Dozel.

speaker: Seliph
text: But of course, Johan. I hope both Grannvale and the world will greatly prosper from your might.

speaker: Johan
text: You shall always have my axe, my liege. I swear to you, the Grannvale throne shall have the undying loyalty of House Dozel.

speaker: Larcei

speaker: Johan
text: Larcei, I…

speaker: Larcei
text: Heh… I know. I mean, I do love you, too, Johan.

speaker: Johan

speaker: Lover

speaker: Johan

speaker: Johan

speaker: Johan

text: I leave Dozel’s care to you, Lord Johalvier.

text: Facing my people ain’t gonna be easy, but one way or another, I’ve gotta atone for my dad’s crimes. Well, I’ve gotta try at least, don’t I? I really owe you one, Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: You truly are an odd one, Lord Johalvier. Your rough words hide a gentle spirit.

speaker: Johalvier
text: Heh, I guess. Talking like that never felt right, yeah? Good luck with everything, Seliph. I’ll see ya around.

speaker: Lover
text: Don’t worry, Lord Seliph. Johalvier’s always been awkward about what really lies  beneath his act…

speaker: Seliph
text: Hahaha, I thought as much. Do take care, Lover… And do take care of Johalvier.

speaker: Lover
text: Yes, sir. I suppose I can’t really afford to leave him be, can I? Rest assured, I’ll look after him. Take care as well, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Lover
text: No need to worry, Lord Seliph! Johalvier’s actually just really shy. That’s why he’s acting so tough.

speaker: Seliph
text: Hahaha, I thought as much. Do take care, Lover… And do take care of Johalvier.

speaker: Lover
text: Yep! I really don’t think leaving him alone’s a good idea, anyways! Don’t worry. I’ll take care of him. You take care of yourself, too, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Seliph
text: I take it you’re headed for Edda, Claude’s son?

speaker: Claude’S Son
text: I am, sir. In the name of my father, Claude, I’ll breathe new life into Edda.

speaker: Seliph
text: Saint Bragi’s prayers are strong indeed. I know your exalted prayers will bring peace to Grannvale and the world.

speaker: Claude’S Son
text: Yes, sir!

speaker: Lover

speaker: Claude’S Son
text: Lover… Are you sure?

speaker: Lover
text: No need to worry, Claude’s son! The kids need my help and I won’t let them down. I’ll never quit on them.

speaker: Lover
text: And you can leave the children to me! I’ll be the mother that they never had, and I’ll make sure they all grow up safely.

speaker: Claude’S Son
text: Lover…

speaker: Lover
text: Heh, relax! I promise, I’m gonna do this right. I’ll take care of all the orphans just as well as if they were my own kids!

speaker: Lover
text: I’ll take care of the orphans, Claude’s son. I’ll do what their mothers no longer can and ensure they all have a good childhood.

speaker: Claude’S Son
text: Lover…

speaker: Lover
text: Don’t worry about a thing. I’ll love and take care of these children, just as much as if they were my own.

speaker: Seliph
text: You’re headed for Edda as well, Claude’s daughter?

speaker: Claude’S Daughter
text: I am. I ought to visit the Edda convent, to properly farewell the war’s fallen…

speaker: Seliph
text: I see… I thought you might, Claude’s daughter. Be sure to pass my gratitude on to the spirits of the dead… Thank you.

speaker: Claude’S Daughter
text: You take care as well, Lord Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: You’re headed for Edda as well, Claude’s daughter?

speaker: Seliph

speaker: Seliph
text: Azelle’s son, I can’t bring myself to hate Lord Arvis any longer. Knowing now he was but a sad victim of fate, I can only offer you my condolences.

speaker: Azelle’S Son
text: Thank you so much, Lord Seliph… The Fire Emblem, House Velthomer’s royal crest, was once revered by people the world over as a symbol of justice. I’ll work tirelessly until the Emblem’s honor and good name are restored.

speaker: Lover
text: I’ll go to Velthomer as well, Azelle’s son.

speaker: Azelle’S Son
text: You will, Lover…?

speaker: Lover
text: Mm. I won’t let you face this alone. So long as we’re together, I know we can survive any hardship!

text: Mm. I can’t just let you go alone, can I? So long as we’re together, I know we can endure most anything.

speaker: Lover

speaker: Seliph

speaker: Oifey
text: Well, sire… I’m leaving for Chalphy now.

speaker: Seliph
text: What? Why, Oifey? Why?! I thought you would never leave my side! I… I still need you!

speaker: Oifey
text: No, sire… You will do a magnificent job ruling on your own. I know it. And whilst you do, it’ll be my duty to protect House Chalphy in your stead.

speaker: Seliph
text: Chalphy… I understand, Oifey. You are right, of course. I won’t be able to inherit its throne, which leaves you as the last bearer of the blood of Baldr who can claim it. I suppose there isn’t much choice…

speaker: Oifey
text: Everything will be alright, sire. I’ll always be watching over you, even from Chalphy.

speaker: Seliph
text: Oifey… To me, you will always be like the father I never had. You taught me all I know… How to strategize, how to live as a knight does… And how to be kind. You’ve done so much, and I could never thank you nearly enough....

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire… I, too, owe your father dearly for all he once did for me. When my parents died, Lord Sigurd took me into his home. He loved me just as if I were his own brother. And yet… I couldn’t even be by his side in his final moments… ... I was such a coward.

speaker: Seliph
text: Oifey… Please don’t cry… This is my fault, not yours…

speaker: Oifey
text: Sniff… My apologies, sire… You shouldn’t have seen that. Now, then… Please, sire…

speaker: Seliph
text: I know, Oifey… I know. You take care as well…

speaker: Lover
text: Don’t worry about a thing, sir. Leave Oifey to me!

speaker: Seliph
text: Ah, right… You’re bound for Chalphy as well, Lover?

speaker: Lover
text: Yep. Oifey’s gone and run himself ragged. He needs rest, and lots of it. It’s up to me to make sure he gets a bit of quiet time.

speaker: Seliph
text: I couldn’t agree more. I trust you’ll take good care of Oifey, Lover.

speaker: Lover
text: Yes, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Lover
text: You can rest easy, Lord Seliph. Leave Oifey to me!

speaker: Seliph
text: Ah, right… You’re bound for Chalphy as well, Lover?

speaker: Lover
text: I am. Oifey is awfully fatigued, and is in dire need of rest. I want to ensure he’ll have a bit of peace and quiet.

speaker: Seliph
text: I couldn’t agree more. I trust you’ll take good care of Oifey, Lover.

speaker: Lover
text: Yes, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Ced

speaker: Seliph
text: Destined for Silesse, then, Ced?

speaker: Ced
text: I am. I’ve left the Silessian people waiting long enough. I’ll be joining them in the effort to restore Silesse once I get home. I’ll give it nothing less than I have!

speaker: Seliph
text: I see. Well, if you’re lending your power to the cause, then I know Silesse is in most capable hands. Take care, Ced the Brave.

speaker: Ced
text: You too, sire!

speaker: Seliph
text: Hm? I take it you’re going to Silesse as well, then, Lover?

speaker: Lover
text: Yeah, I’m going with Ced…

speaker: Seliph
text: Well, congratulations. I pray you two will have many happy years together.

speaker: Lover
text: Thanks, sir!

speaker: Seliph
text: Hm? I take it you’re going to Silesse as well, then, Lover?

speaker: Lover
text: Mm. I’ll be accompanying Ced…

speaker: Seliph
text: Well, congratulations. I pray you two will have many happy years together.

speaker: Lover
text: Thank you, sir.

speaker: Seliph
text: You’re headed for Silesse, then, Fee?

speaker: Fee
text: Yep!

speaker: Seliph
text: Is Mahnya the pegasus in good health?

speaker: Fee
text: Only the best!

speaker: Seliph
text: And the lady herself, Fee?

speaker: Fee
text: Of course! Raring to go!

speaker: Seliph
text: Heh, that’s our Fee.

speaker: Fee
text: Hang on, so if I weren’t so cheery, then I wouldn’t even be me anymore? Is that what you were trying to say, sir?

speaker: Seliph
text: Er… How did you guess?

speaker: Fee
text: Hmph, that’s not very nice! Anyway… Bye, Lord Seliph! Take care of yourself!

speaker: Lewyn’S Son
text: Well, Lord Seliph, thanks for everything. I’ll be going back to Silesse with Father now.

speaker: Seliph
text: I must admit, Lewyn’s son. I’m almost envious you have a father like Lewyn by your side. How nice that must be!

speaker: Lewyn’S Son
text: It is. I’m so proud to be his son, sir. And someday, hopefully, I’ll be every bit the great man he is now.

speaker: Lover
text: Lord Seliph! I’ll be going to Silesse with Lewyn’s son.

speaker: Seliph
text: You will as well, Lover? That’s very reassuring. I pray you and Lewyn’s son will pool your might to aid Silesse’s people.

speaker: Lover
text: Got it! I’ll do my best!

speaker: Lewyn
text: Look after Lewyn’s son, okay, Lover? Silesse is both of yours to rule now. I’m not going back.

speaker: Lover
text: I’ll be accompanying Lewyn’s son back to Silesse, Lord Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: You will as well, Lover? That’s very reassuring. I pray you and Lewyn’s son will pool your might to aid Silesse’s people.

speaker: Lover
text: Yes, Lord Seliph!

speaker: Lewyn
text: Look after Lewyn’s son, okay, Lover? Silesse is both of yours to rule now. I’m not going back.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Silesse is yours to rule now, Lewyn’s son. I’m not going back.

speaker: Lewyn’S Son
text: Huh? What are you talking about, Father?! The war is over! Please… Please, you’ve got to come home!

speaker: Lewyn
text: No. My work there is done. I don’t belong on the throne. Silesse needs a fresh start with its leadership, just like everywhere else. What Silesse needs is you. It needs to be guided by your youthful hand.

speaker: Lewyn’S Son
text: I don’t understand… Silesse needs you, too… And I need you. Please, Father… Please! Come home with me!

speaker: Lewyn
text: Settle down, Lewyn’s son. You’re embarrassing me here. You already know exactly why I’m doing this… Don’t you, Lewyn’s son?

speaker: Lewyn’S Son
text: ...Father…

speaker: Lewyn’S Daughter
text: Hold it right there, Father! What kind of sorry excuse is that?! Are you seriously saying you’re going to up and abandon us AGAIN? No, I don’t think so! Why exactly do you need to do this?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Lewyn’s daughter… Please… This is hard enough without you carrying on…

speaker: Lewyn’S Daughter
text: ...Father…

speaker: Lewyn
text: ...That’s enough. There’s nothing left to say! Go! I leave Silesse’s fate to you…

speaker: Lewyn
text: Well, Seliph, I guess this is farewell for me as well. I’ve got a journey of my own to begin…

speaker: Seliph
text: Thank you, Lewyn… Thank you so much… You’ve done so much for us, the young generation. You’ve always guided us… From the bottom of our hearts, thank you.

speaker: Lewyn
text: I did only my duty, Seliph. I am the wind, a wind fated to guide the beating light of life. And this very light shines on within the hearts of every last one of you.

speaker: Seliph
text: I understand now… All my life, I’ve heard tales about how the dragonkin feared becoming entangled in the sorry affairs of mankind. But you were different… You guided us where your kin never would. So long as the world lives on, humanity will never forget your kindness.. Lewyn… No… A hero of a distant land… Forseti of the Wind…

speaker: Chagall
text: Is the army ready to move in? Those fools couldn't possibly see this coming. Right, as arranged. Move out! This is our final chance to return Agusty to our control. Just look at them... Lingering in my kingdom, oh-so-carefree. ...I grow weary of them. They will pay dearly for this! Jacoban! Where's that lousy sellsword gotten to this time?!

speaker: Jacoban
text: Need me, do you?

speaker: Chagall
text: I've seen just how good a fighter you are. You're in charge of the castle defenses.

speaker: Jacoban
text: Yeah, I know... Might be a boring job, but you're payin' awfully well for it. Let's see 'em learn to fear my bolt sword.

speaker: Chagall
text: That's what I like to hear. Don't fail me.

speaker: Chagall
text: Now, Eldigan's still at Silvail, is he? Hm... How will he take this? I wonder…

speaker: Soldier
text: Milord, we have a problem! The Madino army appears to be preparing for battle!

speaker: Eldigan
text: What?! What is His Majesty thinking, doing something so rash? Blast... To think, we were so close to returning Agusty to him! Gah... I couldn't possibly fight Sigurd. What in the world can I do now…

speaker: Duval
text: Oi, cap'n! Looks like the mainland down south's gettin' ready for 'nother war. This is gettin' interestin'... This is our chance, I reckon, with nuthin' stoppin' us from fleecin' the villages. Both them armies'll be at each other's throats, so there'll be nobody interested in gettin' between us an' th' villages.

speaker: Brigid
text: Shut it, Duvall! I won't allow any petty thefts under my watch. I refuse to let us sink so low. Don't forget, we're heroic thieves. That's what the name of Orgahil now means to the world!

speaker: Duval
text: Bah! What self-respectin' pirate just lets the loot sit there an' does nothing?! The cap'n's gone soft!

speaker: Pizare
text: Now, now. Calm down, Duvall, me mate. I've got me a li'l idea. That wench struts aroun' like the boss, but she ain't really the ol' cap'n's sprog. The cap'n jus' found 'er lost when she as a tiny thing an' raised 'er as 'is own. She still took over when 'e died, but little she knows she ain't really his brat. She ain't the real boss, so there's nuffin' t'worry 'bout. Now, let's go 'elp ourselves to sum treasure!

speaker: Oifey
text: Dire news, sire! King Chagall's army has struck, and they have the castle surrounded!

speaker: Sigurd
text: What?! That fool... We were so close to finally withdrawing from Agustria. There's no sense in attacking us now! Where in blazes is Eldigan...

speaker: Oifey
text: That isn't all, sire. It appears that pirates from Orgahil are attacking amidst the confusion.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Is that so... I suppose we've no choice, then. Ready everyone for battle.

speaker: Deirdre
text: My love... You're about to fight again, aren't you?

speaker: Sigurd
text: I'm afraid so. I'm sorry, Deirdre, but you mustn't come with me this time. Seliph is but a newborn, and he needs you.

speaker: Deirdre
text: Yes, dear...

speaker: Sigurd
text: You needn't look so anxious, Deirdre. I'll be back before long. I promise. Shannan, I've a favor to ask of you. Would you look after Deirdre and Seliph, please?

speaker: Shannan
text: Of course! Don't worry about a thing.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Ha! As spirited as ever, Shannan. At the very least, Deirdre, he ought to keep you in good cheer. Don't worry about a thing, Deirdre. I'll be back for you. I promise.

speaker: Deirdre
text: Milord…

speaker: Knight
text: We're not involved in this battle, on Lord Eldigan's orders. Move along.

speaker: Oifey
text: King Chagall is nowhere to be found, sire.

speaker: Sigurd
text: I see... He must have fled to Castle Silvail, Eldigan is still posted there, after all. His Cross Knights are the last remains of Agustria's army. At this rate, all should be well if we can subdue them, but…

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire, we have a visitor. Father Claude of Edda has just arrived.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Father Claude?! See him in, please.

speaker: Claude
text: It's been a long time, Lord Sigurd. We need to talk. I regret to say that I bring dreadful news from the fatherland.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What is it, Your Grace? What in the world could have happened?

speaker: Claude
text: Prince Kurth is dead. Somebody murdered him en route from Isaach.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What?! This can't be... Who could have done this?

speaker: Claude
text: Lord Byron was once constantly by His Highness's side... Yet, ever since his murder, he has been nowhere to be found. I regret to say this, but... As it stands, Lord Byron - your father - is the prime suspect.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Wh-what?! That's impossible!

speaker: Claude
text: I regret to say that there's been naught but horrid rumors in Grannvale lately. Among them are those which allege that you and your father worked in concert to assassinate the prince... Alas, His Majesty's anguish at the affair has rendered him dreadfully ill.

speaker: Sigurd
text: My father was already the prince's closest confidant. What could he have possible gained from the prince's demise?! Surely, shouldn't Reptor, Langobalt, and the others who opposed the prince be the likely culprits?

speaker: Claude
text: I am of the same mind, but we've no evidence tying either to the crime. And Reptor and his minions currently hold a great sway over the royal court.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What about Lord Arvis, His Majesty's aide? Do you know where he stands on this?

speaker: Claude
text: I cannot say for sure. He seems to hold no enmity toward you, but I am loath to consider him an ally...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm... I'm worried for my father. If I could, I'd head home now and do what I can to help, but my orders haven't changed. I still need to hold Agustria. Please, Your Grace... Do you have any idea what I should do?

speaker: Claude
text: I am on my way to the Tower of Bragi, on the island to the north-west of here. As an heir to the great Saint Bragi, if I pray at our sacred tower, then the truth shall be revealed to me alone. With this knowledge, I can convince His Majesty of Byron's innocence. You needn't worry, Lord Sigurd.

speaker: Tailtiu
text: Claaaaaude! C'mon, let's go! Stop chewing off the poor man's ear. I'm getting bored here.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm? Aren't you Tailtiu of House Friege? What are you doing with Father Claude?

speaker: Tailtiu
text: Wouldn't you worry if I left him to wander all on his lonesome? Somebody's got to protect him.

speaker: Sigurd
text: But you're Duke Reptor's daughter, so...

speaker: Tailtiu
text: I just can't wrap my head around Father's schemes, y'know? Besides, I love the priest!

speaker: Claude
text: Gods, give me strength to cope with this child... Anyway, I'll rendezvous with your group once I've learned the truth. I pray we'll both return home this day.

speaker: Sigurd
text: As do I, Father Claude. As do I. I can't thank you enough.

speaker: Deirdre
text: Shannan, did you hear the news? Sigurd has captured Madino Castle. I... I need to see him again!

speaker: Shannan
text: Deirdre, no! I can't let you do that. It's still too dangerous to go out there now, and Seliph still needs you!

speaker: Deirdre
text: I know. I want you to look after Seliph while I'm gone.

speaker: Shannan
text: No way! I'm just a kid. I can't look after a baby all by myself.

speaker: Deirdre
text: I won't be long. I promise. Please, Shannan... I implore you...

speaker: Shannan
text: Okay, fine. I'll look after him. Just be careful out there and get back here as soon as you can, okay?

speaker: Deirdre
text: Thank you, Shannan. I'm sorry, Seliph. I'll be back for you right away.

speaker: Manfroy
text: Sigyn's daughter... I've found you at last...

speaker: Deirdre
text: Oh? Who are you? Wait... How do you know my mother?

speaker: Manfroy
text: Kehehehe... The day of your rebirth is upon us. Through my black magic, the slate of your life will be cleansed, paving the way for your true husband... Your fate was written the day you were born. There is no use in fighting destiny.

speaker: Deirdre
text: Wh-what are you doing?! Stop it! No!! ...Aaaah... Sig... u... r…

speaker: Chagall
text: And just what do you think you are doing, Eldigan?! If you hadn't dawdled away your day here, then perhaps we wouldn't have lost Madino! Ah, but that's part of your plan, isn't it?! You're part of their plot to destroy Agustria, traitor!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Your Majesty... How could you say that?

speaker: Chagall
text: What's this? Do you dare to be displeased? To think, you've forgotten my father's favor, all to idly stall for time... You're a disgrace to the knighthood!

speaker: Eldigan
text: There's nothing more I can do to convince you... Very well, Your Majesty. My men and I will move out post-haste. I am proud to be a paladin of Agustria. If I must die, it shall be with sword in hand! By your leave, Your Majesty.

speaker: Eldigan
text: This is it, men. It's time for us to enter the fray... Perhaps for the last time. I count myself the luckiest commander there is for your years of loyalty to me. The fatherland's fate hinges on this final battle. Do not let Agustria down. Cross Knights! MOVE OUT!

speaker: Chagall
text: Eldigan's finally moved out, has he? Pompous twit... The rest of you, fortify the defenses! I'm in command now!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Eldigan, please! Lay down your sword! I don't want to fight you! I still have every intention of returning Agusty to Chagall! All I need is a little more time, I swear!

speaker: Eldigan
text: ...Sigurd. I'm sorry, but I grow weary of these excuses. We stand now as two knights on the battlefield, sword to an honorable duel. Draw, Sigurd! So long as I wield the demon blade, Mystletainn, I won't be the one to fall this day!

speaker: Sigurd
text: W... Why... Why did this happen? Why couldn't we save Eldigan?! Has this damned war been in vain all along...

speaker: Oifey
text: I'm sorry, sire, but there was nothing you could have done. I know it hurts, but... For now, the best we can do is work to realize Eldigan's wishes, and give the Agustria people the peace they deserve.

speaker: Chagall
text: Travant! I trust your wyvern rider unit is ready?

speaker: Travant
text: You can rest assured, Chagall. We'll deliver on your expectations.

speaker: Chagall
text: Hmph. I suppose even these common sellswords ought to do a better job for me than all of my worthless servants... Don't you dare let me down!

speaker: Papillon
text: Pick up the pace! Agustria's right ahead! Our targets are the knights of Grannvale. Take your fill of battle! Sear the name of Thracia into the memories of this land!

speaker: Travant
text: Ugh... Papillon failed, did he? That does it. It's time to withdraw. I refuse to fall with this flaming wreck of a country. Heh, farewell, King Chagall... You fool.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Eldigan...

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire... I know this is hard, but please, you mustn't lose heart just yet. By the way, Shannan has just arrived from Agusty. He'd like a word with you, sire.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Shannan?

speaker: Shannan
text: Sigurd! I'm sorry... I'm so, so sorry!

speaker: Sigurd
text: What's happening, Shannan? Why are you crying?

speaker: Shannan
text: Deirdre's gone! She left the castle and was looking to talk to you, but she never returned. I'm sorry! I failed to protect her...

speaker: Sigurd
text: What?! This can't be happening! And Seliph... Shannan, what about my son?

speaker: Shannan
text: I've got Seliph with me. See? Here he is. But Deirdre...

speaker: Sigurd
text: I see... Shannan, this isn't your fault. Don't worry about it. We'll find her. No matter what it takes, I'll find her.

speaker: Shannan
text: B-but, I... I should've tried harder to stop her! I'm so sorry, Sigurd!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre... Where could you be…

speaker: Duvall
text: Cap'n! Big news! Agustria's lost th' war! S'only a matter of time b'fore them Grannvale guys're bangin' down our doors too, eh? What d'ya say?

speaker: Brigid
text: Damn it, Duvall! The only reason they're coming is because you lot all went pillaging, against my orders! You've got nobody but yourself to blame!

speaker: Duvall
text: Keh, enough! I can't take yer arrogance anymore! Shut it an' open yer ears! Ya actually ain't the daughter o' the late cap'n, y'know. Yer just some li'l girl what the boss found, cryin' alone in this ship we raided. Th'boss jus' picked ya up an' raised ya 'imself. 'Fore we knew it, ya'd all grown up an' were bossin' us all 'round, all nonsense-like!

speaker: Brigid
text: W-what?! I... that's...

speaker: Duvall
text: But yer li'l act's worn its welcome out. No point keepin' ya 'live, eh?

speaker: Brigid
text: Damn it all... You really think you clowns can take me that easy?!

speaker: Duvall
text: Get 'er, boys! Kill 'er quick-like! Don't let 'er escape! Pizare, yer in charge o' the boys. Go raise a li'l hell over 'n Agustria! I'll be waitin' back at th' castle.

speaker: Pizare
text: Aye, boss!

speaker: Pizare
text: Righ', raise the bridge! Agustria's all ours!

speaker: Tailtiu
text: Claaaaaude! C'mon, c'mon, c'mon! Aren't' you done praying already? Just look around! There'll be pirates all over us if we don't get moving!

speaker: Claude
text: Be at peace, Tailtiu. This was quite the fruitful journey! Lord Bragi has answered my prayers and revealed to me the truth. It is precisely as I had thought. Not to mention, I even found House Edda's long-lost sacred heirloom within the tower: the staff of Valkyria. See? This is it.

speaker: Tailtiu
text: What, that grubby little cane?

speaker: Claude
text: ...Tailtiu, please. Do try to mind your manners. This is a legendary magical staff with the power to restore life to the deceased. It is usable only be the direct descendants of Saint Bragi. That is to say, me alone.

speaker: Tailtiu
text: Huh. So what you're saying is, with this rod you could bring my sweet old grandma back to life?

speaker: Claude
text: Alas, most likely not. Valkyria is limited in many particular ways, and so cannot be used on just any lost soul. You see, all of mankind is born bearing a life force called quintessence, which-

speaker: Tailtiu
text: Yaaawn... Er, what's that? You lost me. Why're you still talking about this, anyway? We've still gotta get outta here!

speaker: Claude
text: Ah, of course. Let us go.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Good. We've subdued the pirate castle. Oifey, would you please gather our troops here? Now that this is all over, I'd like to ensure that everyone's alright.

speaker: Oifey
text: At once, sire.

speaker: Langobalt
text: Is the army ready? Good. All units, move in! Apprehend the traitor Sigurd and his cohorts! Seize these vile allies of Byron, accomplices to his murder of Kurth and his bid to take over the kingdom! It is the will of His Majesty! No mercy for enemies of the state!

speaker: Reptor
text: Kehehe... Oh, Langobalt. Such audacity! To think, he personally put an end to that miserable prince and nearly killed Byron for putting up a fight... I've never seen such a bold ploy! And with Arvis using His Majesty's trust, it all worked flawlessly! Convincing the king of anything is hardly a challenge, but to succeed with a tale of this scale takes quite the storyteller... And here we are, the entirety of House Chalphy framed for the crime! Heh heh... Our victory is all but assured. The throne of Grannvale shall be mine, one way or another. I'll leave no pest who dares interfere with me alive…

speaker: Sigurd
text: What in blazes is this?! I'm a traitor now, and a Grannvale legion now waits at our doorstep to arrest me?!

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire, and to think, the war here was over at long last, and you were about to go and search for Deirdre.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Gah... How could His Majesty have fallen for Reptor's lies? How could he possibly believe that my father, of all people, would kill Prince Kurth?! Aah... If only Father Claude had gotten back to the capital before they struck... Why?! Why is this happening?! I fought a pointless war, I let Eldigan die, and now this! What have I been fighting for all along?!

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire…

speaker: Annand
text: Lord Sigurd, I presume? I am Annand, a knight in the service of Silesse. Queen Rahna bade my corps and I to come and retrieve you. We invite you and your subordinates to retreat with us to Silesse, until your good name has been cleared in Grannvale.

speaker: Sigurd
text: ...Queen Rahna of Silesse, you say? Why is Silesse willing to give aid to an alleged traitor like me?

speaker: Annand
text: Please, sir. Time is of the essence. The Grannvale assault is sure to begin at any moment now. My pegasus knights will escort you across the sea to safety in Silesse.

speaker: Politician
text: Oh? Here to help, are ya? Huzzah! The village is saved! We can't thank ya enough, but mayhap this magic staff'll help ya out. They call it a Restore staff. If yer allies've been put t'sleep or silenced, one cast of this staff'll get 'em back on their feet. This oughta be a big help for ya.

speaker: Young Woman
text: Ah... the Cross Knights. Lord Eldigan's elite knightly battalion. Their might is legendary, and none in Jugdral can even compare to them. Actually... My boyfriend is a Cross Knight! Hee hee... amazing, isn't it? Don't be shy. Drink up! Well, how 'bout that? Feel the might swellin' in yer muscles! Oughta make yer work out there so much easier.

speaker: Young Woman
text: Sniff... I can't believe it. My boyfriend died in this blasted war. Damn the Grannvale army... No, no... Damn King Chagall! This is all his fault!

speaker: Old Man
text: Oho! Glad to see ya've come. I got this 'ere sword for ya in 'preciation. They call it the wingslayer. It's enchanted to be lethal to sky-riders. If it flies, this sword'll bring it down. 'Course, if ya can't use it, sell it!

speaker: Man
text: No matter how much I think about it, I just don't get why the Orgahil pirates have so suddenly turned on us like this. We could've sworn that boss of theirs was a good lass... Brigid or something, was it?

speaker: Old Woman
text: Oh, it's so nice to see visitors! How 'bout a little somethin' for yer troubles? Here, take a draught of our secret medicine.

speaker: Young Man
text: Hey, be careful out there! Rumor has it that King Chagall's got the infamous Thracian wyvern riders on his payroll. Don't think there's been a war lately where someone or other didn't hire 'em. They're like a pack of hyenas descendin' on fresh prey: brutal and indiscriminate. Nothin' survives in their wake…

speaker: Woman
text: We're so glad to see you! Here, have a quick sip of our local special brew. For generations, it's made us all hardier!

speaker: Woman
text: Ugh. I can't stand people like you who've nothin' better to do than start more wars! Why are you even here? We've absolutely nothin' to do with Agustria or Grannvale! Look. If you've really gotta fight, take it somewhere else, you thoughtless sod.

speaker: Lex
text: Ayra! Hey there.

speaker: Ayra
text: Sigh... What do you want, Lex?

speaker: Lex
text: Sheesh! Courteous as ever, aren't you?

speaker: Ayra
text: Look, get to your point, whatever it may be. I've better things to do than waste time on you.

speaker: Lex
text: Hold on. I've got a little gift here. I thought of you the moment I saw it.

speaker: Ayra
text: You can foist it on some other woman. I've no use for such trinkets.

speaker: Lex
text: Heh... Not even something like this?

speaker: Ayra
text: Oh? ...Wait! That's-

speaker: Lex
text: Ah, good! You're well acquainted with the famous brave sword, then.

speaker: Ayra
text: I never thought I'd see a real brave sword! Never have I seen a blade so beautiful...

speaker: Lex
text: Glad you like it! It's yours. I guess I'll see you around, Ayra.

speaker: Ayra
text: Er, Lex! Wait a moment!

speaker: Ayra
text: Oh…

speaker: Holyn
text: Hey, Ayra! This is for you. Here.

speaker: Ayra
text: Isn't this a brave sword? Why me, though? Shouldn't you be wielding this yourself?

speaker: Holyn
text: This thing's only gonna get harder from here, yeah? You burn through blades so fast you could do with a spare or two. Look after yourself out here, okay? One day I might not be here to watch your back.

speaker: Ayra
text: Holyn... Thank you. I promise I'll put it to good use.

speaker: Lachesis
text: Brother, stop! It's me, Lachesis! This pointlessness has gone on long enough! Your actions are utterly baffling! Would you really betray Sigurd, your friend? Is this what you call a knight's pride?! Please, brother! Believe in Sigurd. Give him even the tiniest amount more time to finish his job. We don't need to fight.

speaker: Eldigan
text: Lachesis... Look, don't cry. Fighting is my only choice. Please don't make this harder than it already is. His Majesty's death will spell the death of Agustria, too, and I cannot allow that.

speaker: Lachesis
text: That isn't true! Everything hinges on Chagall laying down his arms. Sigurd never had any interest in fighting, and has even less interest in continuing if you stop. Brother... Please. You lead the Cross Knights! Chagall simply cannot ignore your counsel!

speaker: Eldigan
text: ...You're right, Lachesis. I'll try and persuade His Majesty, one more time. If I must risk my life, I'd rather risk it to stop this blasted war than to fight my friend. Any knight would do the same. Lachesis... here. This sword is for you.

speaker: Lachesis
text: Isn't this an earth sword?! ...Brother, you can't be-

speaker: Eldigan
text: This is a last memento, in case I... I'm sorry, Lachesis. You must survive!

speaker: Lachesis
text: W-wait! Stop! Don't go, Eldie!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Your Majesty, please order a retreat! There's no use in continuing this fight. Agusty shall be returned to Your Majesty someday, but it must happen peacefully.

speaker: Chagall
text: Eldigan! How dare you abandon the battle to spout such nonsense! You couldn't hide your true colors forever, traitor! Men! Seize this... this worm! Off with his head! Humiliate him! Parade his shame before the world!

speaker: Eldigan
text: I... this was all in vain... This spells Agustria's doom-

speaker: Chagall
text: Tch, enough! Accept your death quietly, traitor! Finish him! Do it, right here, right NOW!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Lachesis…

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Pardon me, dear... But I think I owe you an apology.

speaker: Quan
text: Eh? What's happened, Ethlyn? By the look of it, it must be grave indeed...

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Here. Take this.

speaker: Quan
text: A spear? ...What?! I-isn't this Gáe Bolg?! Why do you-

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Your lord father entrusted it to me, Quan. He thought it prudent for you to have it at hand, in case our battles grew too fierce.

speaker: Quan
text: Even just holding it, I've seldom felt so strong! Why did you wait till now, though?

speaker: Ethlyn
text: With the spear, your lord father also passed onto me its tale... I'm so sorry...

speaker: Quan
text: ...Aye. Gáe Bolg bears the baggage of a truly sad legend. But that is all it is: a legend.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: But-

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn, trust me. Triumph is within our grasp this day. I'll not fall victim to an old myth. I'll not let it stop me from returning home. Our dear little Altena still awaits us, and I'll not allow some fairy tale to disappoint her.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Yes... Quan, no matter what happens... We'll never lose each other... Right?

speaker: Quan
text: Ah, you're concerned about Deirdre, aren't you... There's nothing to worry about. It won't be long until we find her.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Yes... I want to believe she'll be okay, too. I wish I could believe it. But...

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn? Come now! Dry your tears. Do you truly feel so bad about this?

speaker: Ethlyn
text: I... Yes... Knowing th-that Sigurd and Deirdre may never meet again... Th-they love each other so... so much... Why, Quan... Why did this happen to them?!

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn…

speaker: Sigurd
text: Are you holding up okay, Brigid?

speaker: Brigid
text: Huh? Who're you? Wait... How do you know my name?!

speaker: Sigurd
text: The villagers told me of a woman who leads the pirates of Orgahil, and of her devotion to aiding the poor and weak. That would be you, correct?

speaker: Brigid
text: You must be that Grannvale man... Sigurd, right? Guess this is it. Come on. Just get it over with.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Ahahaha! Oh no, you're mistaken! I'm certain not here to kill you. I just want to talk to you, Brigid. I'd like you to ally with us. We'd love to add your strength to our own, to help us better fight the pirates. What say you?

speaker: Brigid
text: Wait. You really want me, of all people?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Certainly! You'd be a tremendous asset.

speaker: Brigid
text: You're a strange little man, Sigurd…

speaker: Midir
text: ...Lady Aideen?

speaker: Brigid
text: Huh? Who're you? You don't look familiar.

speaker: Midir
text: Oh, sorry! You're not her. My mistake. But then, that must make you...

speaker: Brigid
text: What's this you're mumbling about? Speak up, you weird little man!

speaker: Midir
text: Er... May I ask your name?

speaker: Brigid
text: I'm Brigid.

speaker: Midir
text: Brigid... You're gorgeous...

speaker: Brigid
text: Excuse me?! You've gotta be joking!

speaker: Midir
text: I must be dreaming... There's another one... And she's even more beautiful!

speaker: Brigid
text: Ugh... That's it!

speaker: Aideen
text: Pardon me, but are you not... Yes! It is you! My sister! Brigid! I am Aideen, your sister! Surely you recall me?

speaker: Brigid
text: What? How do you know my name? Hang on... You look just like me! Aideen, huh... It sounds kinda familiar... But where from?

speaker: Aideen
text: Brigid, listen well. I am your twin sister! We lost you to pirates years ago, when you were just five years old. I've searched for you for years. I never lost hope that we would meet again.

speaker: Brigid
text: This is all so sudden... No. Weird feelings like this aren't enough! I need proof!

speaker: Aideen
text: Proof, you say? Here. Draw this bow.

speaker: Brigid
text: Huh? Okay, that's a nice bow and all, but what's it gotta do with anything? Guess I'll humor you. So I draw it and- ...Whoa! W-what's going on?! The hell is this...? I... What's this weird feeling boiling within me... Are these memories? Ah... my heart is on fire... Aideen? Yes... I remember now! You're Aideen... my sister.

speaker: Aideen
text: Oh, thank the gods! You remember! That bow is your birthright, Brigid. It is Yewfelle, the sacred bow of Jungby. Legends tell that the exalted weapons of this land, such as this one, can only be wielded by a single heir per generation. For House Jungby and Yewfelle, that rightful heir is you, Brigid. I trust this proof will suffice?

speaker: Brigid
text: Oh, Aideen... Come here... Let me get a good look at you... How's our father doing? And our brother... Andorey, right?

speaker: Aideen
text: I've so much to tell you, too... Brigid... My sister.

speaker: Claude
text: Lord Sigurd! I apologize for the wait.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Father Claude, you're safe! We heard about how you ended up amidst all those pirates. Everyone was so worried.

speaker: Claude
text: I'm glad Tailtiu was close at hand. We may not have survived, if not for her magic. More importantly, Lord Sigurd, my prayers to Saint Bragi were answered.

speaker: Sigurd
text: You have the truth of all this, then?

speaker: Claude
text: That I do. As I thought, Duke Reptor is behind all of this. On his orders, it was Duke Langobalt who killed Prince Kurth. The two then successfully framed your father, Lord Byron, for the crime.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Just as I thought...

speaker: Claude
text: The pair's treachery runs deeper still. The murder of Isaach's King Mananan was also the handiwork of Duke Reptor. He feared a peaceful end to the war would end the sole excuse for the conquest of Isaach, so he secretly had the king killed.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Is that so... Reptor's grubby hands are all over this mess...

speaker: Claude
text: Not quite. In the shade of his avarice, there's something else at work... Something unsettling and terrifying. Not even Lord Bragi could scry this evil presence, obscured by its power as it is.

speaker: Sigurd
text: An evil presence? Could it be that dark priesthood... Wait! What of my father, Claude?

speaker: Claude
text: Lord Byron yet lives, but is injured and weak. I fear he is not long for this world...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Father... This can't be happening...

speaker: Claude
text: I'll hasten back to the capital. His Majesty needs to hear the truth. Lord Sigurd, for the time being, stay here and restrain yourself from rash action.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Understood. I can't thank you enough, Father Claude. I beg of you, do everything you can. Save my father and his good name.

speaker: Claude
text: Our fates lie with the mercy of the gods...

speaker: Dew
text: Oh, whoa! This is that Tower of Bragi place, isn't it? Hee hee! Got a good thiefy feeling about this one! Let's see what it's got…

speaker: Dew
text: Mmm? Nope, nothin' over here. Over there, maybe? ...Aww, man! What a borin' little dump.
...Who... Who are you...

speaker: Dew
text: Huh?!
...State your business...

speaker: Dew
text: Heh, maybe if I pretend I can't hear 'em...
How dare you... defile this sacred ground... ...BEGONE!

speaker: Dew
text: Kyaaa! S-sorry! Please don't hurt me!

speaker: Dew
text: Hah... hah... What just happened?! ...Hang on. A sword? What's it doin' sitting around a place like this? Eh, who cares? Guess I'm gettin' something outta this after all!

speaker: Jacoban
text: Keh... Taste my bolt sword!

speaker: Jacoban
text: S-such a shame…

speaker: Eldigan
text: Those of you who wish not to fall prey to Mystletainn... Stay clear of me, lest your life end on the demon blade!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Sigurd... Never did I suspect our blades would someday cross. ...Yet we are knights. This was always our fate.

speaker: Sigurd
text: E-Eldigan! Wait!!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Lachesis, stop! I will not fight you!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Agustria... I've failed you... Forgive... me…

speaker: Chagall
text: H-how dare you! I am the King of Agustria! You dare show me such disrespect?! Damn it all... I'll show you the penalty for such offense: death!

speaker: Chagall
text: Sigurd! Feel the full force of your months of humiliation of me!

speaker: Sigurd
text: King Chagall, you've done naught but murder countless innocents. ...And Eldigan... You're as foul as they come!

speaker: Chagall
text: Silence, you fool! You understand nothing of me! You die, Sigurd, here and now!

speaker: Chagall
text: Hmhmhm... You're far too late, girl. Eldigan is already long dead.

speaker: Lachesis
text: You... You pig! You butchered my brother! You will not get away with this!

speaker: Chagall
text: My... My Agustria…

speaker: Papillon
text: Heh... Allow me to teach you the terror of the Thracian wyvern riders!

speaker: Papillon
text: Thracia... Glory to... urgh…

speaker: Pizare
text: Them Grannvale guys, huh? Hold still an' let me teach ya t'fear the pirates o' Orgahil!

speaker: Pizare
text: D-damn... Th-the pirates o' Orgahil... Never lose... do we?

speaker: Duvall
text: Ugh, me men're jus' as useless as always! Damn all y'all!

speaker: Duvall
text: N-no... Damn it all...

speaker: Duvall
text: Geh! Yer still clingin' t'life, wench?! Damn yer stubbornness!

speaker: Brigid
text: Duvall! You'll pay through the nose for your treachery!

speaker: Leif
text: Finn, what's the situation? Any word from the other division yet?

speaker: Finn
text: ...We've failed, milord. Every last soldier in the Alster raid is dead. This is a crippling blow to our army. We've lost most of our might in one fell swoop.

speaker: Leif
text: This can't be happening... I thought this was our big chance... Was all of this useless all along? Damn it all! I'll strangle Blume himself with my bare hands!

speaker: Finn
text: Please calm yourself, milord! This isn't the end quite yet. I've just had a word with King Lewyn. He's sending Prince Seliph's liberation army to back us up. Until then, no matter what, milord, we must endure the siege.

speaker: Leif
text: Prince Seliph, you say... He's the son of my father's old friend Sigurd, and of Empress Deirdre, right? I pray we can meet him soon... Perhaps if we merge our efforts with his, we'll have a better chance of protecting people from the Empire.

speaker: Nanna
text: That's right, Leif! Besides, if we just let ourselves lose now, wouldn't your men's death's all be in vain? I think we should abandon the castle for now, and seek refuge near that western church.

speaker: Leif
text: Mm, you're right... I suppose we don't have much of a choice now. Very well. Our priority now is to play this out defensively for the time being. Until Prince Seliph gets here, we must endure…

speaker: Blume
text: What's your problem now?! Can't you capture even as worthless a castle as this? Are you worms taking this seriously?

speaker: General
text: Y-yes, milord... The thing is, though, the enemy is proving to be of a resilient sort. We're struggling to breach their defenses.

speaker: Blume
text: Buffoons, all of you! Do you really think I want to hear excuses? I want Leonster seized! No more delays! If you waste any more time on this, then we'll have to contend with those Isaachian mongrels as well!

speaker: General
text: Y-yes, milord! We will strike immediately, milord!

speaker: Patty
text: Hooboy, those rumors weren't kidding! That place was full to the brim with treasure. Been a long time since I've had a haul like this! But I can't afford to dawdle now. Still gotta get out of here, and quick…

speaker: Shannan
text: Hey, excuse me! Hand that sword over. You can keep everything else, but I need the sword.

speaker: Patty
text: Where do you think you get off, trying to take somebody else's hard-earned goods? Do you have any idea how tough it was to get my hands on this sword? If you want it, come and get it, nincompoop!

speaker: Shannan
text: W-wait!

speaker: Ctuzof
text: What? Thieves have plundered our treasury? And they absconded with Balmung?! You fools! Go seize them! Now!

speaker: Dark Mage
text: Y-yes, Your Grace... But, er, Your Grace... Surely a master of dark magics of your caliber could crush common thieves such as these with a single blow, even from here?

speaker: Ctuzof
text: I've misplaced my Book of Fenrir... My men are scouring the shrine to find it, but so far it has yet to emerge...

speaker: Dark Mage
text: Understood, Your Grace. In that case, my clan and I will take a few mercenaries and pursue them. We swear to you, Your Grace, that we will have the treasure back where it belongs post-haste!

speaker: Seliph
text: So the route to Leonster requires that we cross this vast desert, yes?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Yeah... The Yied Shrine's the real problem here, as it's controlled by the Loptyrian Order. The Order's fell mages infest the desert, mercilessly assaulting anyone they find in it. People've taken to calling the region the Desert of Death... A fitting name, really.

speaker: Seliph
text: I can only imagine how awfully travellers struggle here! I wonder... Perhaps it'd be possible to seize the Shrine from the Order.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Heh, I thought you'd never ask. There's always a way, but this one won't be easy. We may need to make sacrifices.

speaker: Seliph
text: So be it. At this point we've little choice. Not to mention, Shannan is likely still in the desert... For now, let's focus on taking control of Yied . All else will begin there!

speaker: Soldier
text: Milord, we've received word that the Isaachian rebels are on the move.

speaker: Bramsel
text: Isaachian rebels? Ah, the ones led by that brat... Celice, was it? Or Serlis? Something like that. Heh... Interesting. Very interesting, indeed! The Empire's put a hefty price on that boy's head. Let's make sure we're the ones to rake in that bounty, shall we? Keep our border locked down for the time being. The best option is to let them run themselves ragged, leaving them wide open to our strike! Instruct Commander Jabarro to put his squad on standby. His services will be needed in short order!

speaker: Lene
text: Hey, what's with all this noise? You're not about to go to war, are you?

speaker: Ares
text: No, we've not entered such a dire state yet. For the time being, we are merely preparing for the arrival of the Isaachian rebel army.

speaker: Lene
text: Oh, that's good. I guess I'm a bit worried about how you're gonna have to go and fight, too, Ares…

speaker: Ares
text: What sorry excuse for a mercenary would I be if I refused to join a battle, Lene? Never mind one which, rumor has it, will oppose Sigurd's son... Never would I deny a chance to personally slay the spawn of my father's mortal foe…

speaker: Lene
text: Hee hee! You're still going on about that, are you? Oh, you dolt. I mean, think about it. Both your father and that Sigurd man were knights, weren't they? And isn't killing part of a knight's job? It's like my job. Sometimes, I've got to dance for foul, leering men! I hate it, but it's part of the work. I have to just deal with it. We've all gotta do what we gotta do to get by in life. I dunno... I just don't think it's right to hate someone for doing their job.

speaker: Ares
text: Lene... I understand. I'll have to think it over for a time, but I do understand…

speaker: Dark Mage
text: Good news, Your Grace. We've found your Book of Fenrir.

speaker: Ctuzof
text: Hmm? Excellent! Heh heh... This will be the end of the road for the rebels! With their dying thoughts, they shall marvel in fear at the terrifying power of Fenrir…

speaker: Seliph
text: So this is the Yied Shrine... It looks so sparse...

speaker: Lewyn
text: The remnants of the Loptyrian Empire have hidden within the depths of the shrine for generations. They had no choice. Trying to build new lives on the surface would have led to their mass persecution, or even being burned at the stake. I suspect that at first they weren't really bad or unusual people, but before long, their life here twisted them into what we know them as today.

speaker: Seliph
text: I can hardly believe it... It's as if they were all being tortured for the sins of their long-dead Imperial ancestors... All my life, these people have been branded as the "dark cult", or the "devil's kin"... I can barely imagine their pain... Hold a moment. This scribble on the wall... Is that a child's penmanship? It's a prayer... And it begs for the return of the dark god... ...Was Loptous the only hope these people had?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Yeah... Consider this a lesson, Seliph. Good and evil can't be easily reduced to such simple, black-and-white ideals. If you must hate, hate the evil which lurks in us all, not the individual. Never forget this.

speaker: Bramsel
text: Yied's fallen, has it? Heh... Perfect. Open our borders! We'll let them proceed through toward Fort Melgen, let them wear themselves out some more, then strike their wide-open backs! Kehehe... It's almost too easy to be any fun! Wouldn't you say, Jabarro?

speaker: Jabarro
text: Heh, just another hard day's work for you, sir... But hey, so long as you're payin' the bills, my men've got nothin' to complain 'bout. 'Bout time we had a good fight, anyhow.

speaker: Ishtore
text: Hmm... The rebels have already taken Yied? Liza, what do you make of the situation?

speaker: Liza
text: I suspect their most likely aim is to come to the aid of the Leonster rebels. As it stands, Ishtore, your father is still preoccupied besieging them at Leonster. Should they reach Alster and strike while he's occupied, the results would be disastrous... It is imperative that we intercept them here and now. Our force will be more than enough.

speaker: Ishtore
text: Indeed... My lord father could use the aid. Liza, may I place you in command of my army?

speaker: Liza
text: Certainly. Leave everything to me, milord.

speaker: Ishtore
text: I confess I'd rather keep you away from the eye of the storm, but there's nobody whom I could ever trust more than you. My apologies, Liza.

speaker: Liza
text: I... Rest assured, milord. You've nothing to worry about. Just... Please, Ishtore, be careful... Now, excuse me... Men, move out! Assume your positions!

speaker: Bramsel
text: Ohohohoho! Lene, was it? That was quite the dance there! Come hither. I have a little reward for you...

speaker: Lene
text: Eww, how rude! You get off your butt and come over here if you've got something to give me!

speaker: Bramsel
text: Hohoho! As cute as that fiery heart is, mouthing off to me so violently? I can't say I care so much for that. Bring her to me!

speaker: Lene
text: W-what d'you think you're doing?! Let go! Let! Me! Go! You ANIMALS!

speaker: Ares
text: Hold! Take your hands off the girl, craven scum!

speaker: Bramsel
text: What? And who exactly are you? How dare you, a common sellsword, turn your blade on your employer!

speaker: Ares
text: Nobody shall lay a hand on her, lest you face severe consequence. Are we clear?

speaker: Bramsel
text: Gah... What is this sorry little pantomime?! Seize him! End his little life!

speaker: Ares
text: You all see my sword, correct? I trust I need not introduce the demon blade. Beware, for Mystletainn craves the blood of men! Who dares to come forth and slake its thirst?

speaker: Bramsel
text: M-Mystletainn?! That's the one and only demon blade? Th-then you... It can't be...

speaker: Ares
text: Oh, but it can. It is indeed I: Ares, the Black Knight.

speaker: Bramsel
text: M-my deepest apologies, sir! I was merely jesting about! Look, I'll never lay hands on the little darling ever again! You forgive me, right? Right?

speaker: Ares
text: ...Very well. Lene, are you unharmed?

speaker: Lene
text: Yeah... Thank you, Ares...

speaker: Bramsel
text: Gah... Damn them both! I'll make them suffer... You'll see…

speaker: Lewyn
text: At last, Seliph, you've reached Melgen. Leonster's just a stone's throw from here.

speaker: Seliph
text: Say, Lewyn... Will this war ever end? I still doubt that Prince Ishtore or his general were truly wicked people... Must we kill still more like them?

speaker: Lewyn
text: That may be so, but don't forget they still actively served the will of a brutal tyrant. As far as our cause is concerned, there is no doubt. They were the enemy. This is a war, Seliph. There's more to it than only ever fighting the thoroughly evil, or those whom we hate.

speaker: Seliph
text: I suppose so...

speaker: Lewyn
text: Heh! It's okay, Seliph. You're a good man, through and through. You could just stand to worry a bit less. Now, then! We've got our goal to focus on: coming to the rescue over in Leonster.

speaker: Seliph
text: Indeed. Let's move in on Leonster. Everything shall be there!

speaker: Bramsel
text: What? Melgen's fallen already?! Blast! We were too slow! Oh, well. We can still ambush them while they regroup. Men, this is our chance! Jabarro, send in your brigade! Hit them hard while their backs are turned! Leave no survivors!

speaker: Jabarro
text: At once, sir!

speaker: Lene
text: D'you really have to go, Ares? Please don't leave... Please!

speaker: Ares
text: I've little choice in the matter. It was Jabarro who found me as a lost infant, and raised me all these years. I owe him dearly...

speaker: Lene
text: Don't you get it? He's just using your loyalty to treat you like a weapon! I... I hate him so much!

speaker: Ares
text: Lene... No that isn't...

speaker: Lene
text: Okay, fine! Whatever! Go with him, if you love him so much! It's your life to waste, after all! But you can just go forget we ever met!

speaker: Ares
text: Lene…

speaker: Bramsel
text: Hmph... That Ares buffoon has gone, has he? Good riddance…

speaker: Blume
text: Banba! Fetra! Eliu! Deploy at once! I want you to show these rebel pigs just what it is that the Empire can do!

speaker: Banba
text: Yes, milord. Leave it to us.

speaker: Fetra
text: We will never let you down, milord.

speaker: Eliu
text: The rebels shall be destroyed quickly, cleanly, efficiently and utterly. Excuse us, milord.

speaker: Blume
text: Hmm! Everything depends on you. Tine. You, too, will deploy at once.

speaker: Tine
text: ...Y-yes, uncle. As you wish...

speaker: Blume
text: Hmph... One would think I could expect more gratitude from someone I raised out of the goodness of my heart after their mother died. Or have you forgotten my many kindnesses?

speaker: Tine
text: No, uncle...

speaker: Blume
text: Good. Now, get moving. Remember, these rebels are responsible for murdering my dear son, Ishtore, and his true love, Liza! Avenging them is your mission, Tine!

speaker: Blume
text: The rest of you, move out at once! I don't want a single rebel left breathing!

speaker: Banba
text: Fetra. Eliu. I trust you already understand. We must work in absolute, perfect unison. We will be the ones to claim Seliph's head as a trophy this day. We mustn't be beaten by Tine’s unit.

speaker: Tine
text: I don't understand... All the villagers talk of the rebels as if they're liberating heroes... But why... Why did they kill Ishtore? I... I don't know what to do anymore... Oh... Mother... What would you do…

speaker: Bramsel
text: There you are, girlie! How dare you embarrass me like that the other day. It's about time I thanked you properly!

speaker: Lene
text: Oh? And what exactly're you gonna do about it? I see right through you! The moment Ares is nowhere in sight, you think it's okay to act all tough again, you vile louse! Don't even think about coming any closer. I don't need Ares around to stop you!

speaker: Bramsel
text: Of all the nerve... You little wench! Throw her in the dungeon! You'll have plenty of time to think about what you've done there!

speaker: Lene
text: Ahh! No... Ares…

speaker: Jabarro
text: Y'know, I don't get you Ares. Why the hell'd you go and get yourself all cosied up with a broad like that? Oh well, I guess. It's all in the past. You're gonna forget 'er sooner or later.

speaker: Ares
text: I beg your pardon? What exactly are you trying to say, Jabarro?

speaker: Jabarro
text: Heh heh... Oh, nothing. Well, 'cept that I bet Bramsel's right about to...

speaker: Ares
text: T-this can't be... Jabarro! How could you know his foul intent, yet let your tongue lie still before me?!

speaker: Jabarro
text: You can't worry 'bout the fairer sex, Ares. Have your fun with 'em, but never stick around for when their sorry lives come crashin' down...

speaker: Ares
text: How dare you! And to think you held my trust for so long... I must return to Darna! Lene needs me!

speaker: Jabarro
text: Nah, that ain't gonna happen, see. Nobody, and I mean nobody, blows off my orders and turns tail on my watch! Not even you, Ares.

speaker: Ares
text: Keh... I've come far in your company, Jabarro, but our association ends now. If anyone wishes to stop me, Mystletainn will eagerly welcome your necks!

speaker: Jabarro
text: Grr... I'll show you your place, whelp!

speaker: Seliph
text: So this is Darna... The legendary city...

speaker: Lewyn
text: Long ago, at the peak of the old holy war, Darna was the last bastion of the resistance army... It was the last free land in Jugdral. In battle after battle, the overwhelming might of the Loptyrian Empire had devastated the resistance. Ultimately, the last of the resistance soldiers barricaded themselves within Darna's walls. Battered and wounded as they were, they were nonetheless determined to fight to the bitter end. But then, suddenly, there was a miracle... From the heavens descended twelve gods, who bestowed upon twelve young heroes miraculous weapons and immense powers. Thus were born the Twelve Crusaders, the heroes who led the resistance to victory.

speaker: Seliph
text: That was the legendary Miracle of Darna, yes?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Yeah, the very same. And even as we speak, Seliph, another miracle is dawning upon us. Just as the resurrection of Loptous looms on the horizon, so too are the Crusaders themselves arising in our world once more...

speaker: Seliph
text: ...I beg your pardon?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Heh... Don't worry, Seliph. You'll understand soon enough…

speaker: Ares
text: I pray that Lene is still unharmed. I must hasten back to Darna…

speaker: Seliph
text: Right. Leonster is back under our control. That leaves only Alster... Everyone, we've only a little further to go. We can do this!

speaker: Seliph
text: Julia?! You’re safe! Oh, thank heavens…

speaker: Julia
text: Mm… The enemy seized and imprisoned me here, but I knew… I knew you would rescue me, no matter what.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Excellent work, Seliph. Thanks to you, Alster is finally free from the Empire.

speaker: Seliph
text: I wouldn't get too excited, Lewyn. King Blume yet lives. I assume he fled to Connaught amidst the flurry of Alster's capture.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Eh, these sorts of things can't be helped. After all, the war's only just beginning. We're only now starting to carve our foothold in the Thracian Peninsula.

speaker: Seliph
text: And yet, the citizens are already all so eager to support us! I've seldom seen such joy...

speaker: Lewyn
text: For the first time, they've got hope for a future free from the Empire's abuse. You're the people's last hope, Seliph, but the worst of the war still lies ahead, huh?

speaker: Seliph
text: Mm. And yet, I've so much incredible talent fighting by my side! With such amazing men and women with me I know no challenge will be too great!

speaker: Lewyn
text: Yeah... You'll all do just fine, Seliph.

speaker: Young Woman
text: Darna is lorded over by Count Bramsel, who's as revolting as they come! If he isn't playing the slimy sycophant to some visiting Grannvale noble or other, he's prancin' around like he's the gods' gift to kings! Ugh... The sooner somebody sticks a sword through that pig of a man, the better!

speaker: Old Man
text: It ain't that simple, though. Standing between you lot and Bramsel is the best mercenary force his money can buy. One of 'em, Ares, is the strongest of 'em all. He's still just a kid, really, but he's frightfully strong, 'cause he's got this magic blade called Mystletainn. From what I heard, the mercenary captain, Jabarro, found Ares as a wee little kid and took him in. The two're real close, I hear. You ain't got much of a chance against Ares. Sorry to rain on your parade like that, kid. Here, take this shield ring as an apology. You oughta be able to get some use out of this.

speaker: Man
text: Blume's got some terrifying warriors on his side. There's Banba, Fetra and Eliu, a trio of powerful sorceress sisters. Then there's Tine, a young mage... Blume's niece she may be, but that girl's still got a kind heart on her. She's come to our aid and the aid of our neighbor villages time and again... She's nothing like her family…

speaker: Old Man
text: King Blume and his queen, Hilda, have got two children between 'em: Ishtar and Ishtore. Ishtar's ruling over Munster right now, and Ishtore's posted at Fort Melgen, both doing Blume's dirty work. Unlike their folks, they're fine youths. You'll be sure to face 'em sooner or later... Be on your guard, stranger.

speaker: Young Man
text: Near the end of the war all those years ago, this entire region was conquered by King Blume, the son of Duke Reptor. His rule's been one tragedy after another... Just when we thought he couldn't get any worse, now he's just letting those child hunts happen! We can't take this anymore…

speaker: Woman
text: The Empire's brutal rule has broken us so... We can't live like this much longer. Please, I beg of you... Save us all…

speaker: Anna
text: You’re fighting in the war, right? I bet there’s someone you care about who you’re fighting for. My boyfriend set off to fight in the war, too. I’m not exactly a fighter myself. Not much I can do but wait for people like you to finish it… Oh, I know! Here, this charmed blade’ll boost your resistance. Go on. This one’s on the house. Be sure to make some nice, deep cuts in some Imperials for me, won’t you, sweetie?

speaker: Leylia
text: Thanks, miss! I’ll take good care of it. Hey, what’s your name anyway?

speaker: Anna
text: Me? The name’s Anna, and my boyfriend’s called Jake. If you see him, be sure to tell him that Anna’s worried sick!

speaker: Leylia
text: Jake…?

speaker: Old Woman
text: Ahh... The liberation army... It's a blessing to know that Prince Leif has finally taken a stand. Lord Quan... Lady Ethlyn... I pray you're both proud of your son... Please, kind knight, accept this speed ring. I'd like you to wear it proudly to your battles.

speaker: Seliph
text: Shannan! I'm so glad to see you've made it unscathed.

speaker: Shannan
text: Yeah, sorry to worry you like that. You went and took back Isaach behind my back, did you, Seliph? I can't thank you enough!

speaker: Seliph
text: No, we'd still be in Tirnanog if not for you. You inspired us. You gave us your courage. If not for you, we could never have taken to the field!

speaker: Shannan
text: Heh, you're starting to put on a bit of muscle there, aren't you? You're finally starting to...

speaker: Seliph
text: Shannan...?

speaker: Shannan
text: Hm? ...Oh, it's nothing. Pay me no mind, Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: Anyway, we're finally starting to challenge the Empire! Not bad, wouldn't you say?

speaker: Shannan
text: Heh, not bad at all, Seliph! I've waited so long for this day... We all have, really.

speaker: Seliph
text: Thank you, Shannan!

speaker: Larcei
text: Prince Shannan! Whew... Glad to see you're still in one piece!

speaker: Shannan
text: Oh, Larcei! Sorry I wasn't around to see all this begin. From what I've heard, you've all had quite the tough time so far.

speaker: Larcei
text: Don't worry about it! The important part is that you're safe. I, er...

speaker: Shannan
text: How's your sword arm doing? Any stronger?

speaker: Larcei
text: Yeah, but still far below your prowess, sir.

speaker: Shannan
text: How about a quick lesson to patch that up? See, raw power isn't quite enough here. Try putting a bit more spirit into it... and swing!

speaker: Larcei
text: Nnn-yah! Like this, sir...?

speaker: Dermott
text: Excuse me. You wouldn’t happen to be Nanna, would you?

speaker: Nanna
text: I am. And you are?

speaker: Dermott
text: Perfect! I’ve finally found you! I’m your brother, Dermott!

speaker: Nanna
text: Huh?! What… are you talking about?

speaker: Dermott
text: I didn’t know until just now, either. King Lewyn told me everything. In the war seventeen years ago, I was with the kids who fled to Isaach. But you were born after our mother, Lachesis, went to Leonster instead.

speaker: Nanna
text: You… You’re my brother? Then where’s Mother now?!

speaker: Dermott
text: Er… Where’s Mother? What exactly are you getting at here, Nanna?

speaker: Nanna
text: I haven’t seen her in so long… When I was around three years old, she left us and travelled alone to Isaach, to try and find you. She never came back. I’ve waited to see her again for years…

speaker: Dermott
text: She did? But… but I never saw her!

speaker: Nanna
text: You… didn’t? Then where is she…

speaker: Dermott
text: The Yied Desert… It’s a very treacherous place. Very few lone travellers survive it…

speaker: Nanna
text: ...No! Oh, Mother…

speaker: Tristan
text: Excuse me. You wouldn't happen to be Jeanne, would you?

speaker: Jeanne
text: I am. And you are?

speaker: Tristan
text: Perfect! I've finally found you! I'm your brother, Tristan!

speaker: Jeanne
text: Huh?! What... You can't be serious!

speaker: Tristan
text: I'm being completely serious! See, our father was a knight of House Nordion. When we were both still little, he was killed in the Agustrian civil war, and we were adopted by Lord Sgiurd's army. We later fled to Isaach with Sir Oifey, but we somehow lost you along the way...

speaker: Jeanne
text: Huh... That actually fits. I was adopted by a travelling merchant, who once said he found me in Isaach.

speaker: Tristan
text: Yeah... Sir Oifey's always said he wondered if something like that happened.

speaker: Jeanne
text: But then, when I was just seven years old, some Imperial thug murdered him... That's when Finn found and adopted me.

speaker: Tristan
text: Wow... that sounds just awful. I'm sorry you had to deal with that, Jeanne.

speaker: Jeanne
text: No, it's okay. I mean, now I have you! I'm so happy I finally have a brother... Thank you, Tristan! Let's never be parted again…

speaker: Oifey
text: Say, Dermott. You have a sister in Leonster, don't you?

speaker: Dermott
text: Yes, sir. We were separated when we were very young. From what I've heard, she grew up with Sir Finn, a knight of Leonster.

speaker: Oifey
text: Sir Finn, you say... You're eager to have the chance to see her again, aren't you?

speaker: Dermott
text: Yes, sir. I can hardly wait!

speaker: Oifey
text: Heh. You'll have to give this battle your all first, then! How about a quick swordplay lesson?

speaker: Dermott
text: Yes, sir! I'd appreciate that!

speaker: Patty
text: Kyaaaaaaa! Stop! Get your hands off of me!

speaker: Shannan
text: Ugh... Look, I don't want to hurt you. Could you just give me that sword back?

speaker: Patty
text: Wait... give it back? Is it yours?

speaker: Shannan
text: Yes, it is! It's my family's ancestral blade, Balmung. I'm the only person capable of using it. You've nothing at all to gain from keeping it.

speaker: Patty
text: Wait, so how'd this thing end up in Yied, anyway?

speaker: Shannan
text: It belonged to my father, who died in Grannvale's war with Isaach. Someone must've stolen it from him after he died. I only recently learned that it was being kept at Yied, so I came to retrieve it.

speaker: Patty
text: Hang on, hang on, hang on! Could it be... Are you Isaach's Prince Shannan?!

speaker: Shannan
text: I am...

speaker: Patty
text: Really? It's really, really you?! Wow! Oh my gosh, this is incredible!

speaker: Shannan
text: Er...

speaker: Patty
text: No, really, I've heard all the stories about you! All of them! I've been a huge fan of yours for so long, but I never thought I'd actually meet you!

speaker: Patty
text: But you're here! You're really here talking to me right now! It's like all of my dreams've come true!

speaker: Shannan
text: ...Yeah, I think I get the idea. My sword, please.

speaker: Patty
text: Oh, right! Sorry. Here ya go!

speaker: Shannan
text: Balmung... My holy sword... It's finally mine... Hm? Ahh! What is this power...?!

speaker: Patty
text: Wooow! This is incredible…

speaker: Leif
text: Lord Seliph! What an honor it is to meet you at last. I'm Leif, the son of King Quan of Leonster.

speaker: Seliph
text: The honor is all mine, Prince Leif! I'm glad to see you've made it thus far unharmed.

speaker: Leif
text: My parents both died in the Battle of Belhalla's prelude... They were felled by a Thracian ambush. My homeland, Leonster, soon found itself in the clutches of an Imperial occupation, and fell under the reign of its Duke Blume. If not for my knight, Finn, I wouldn't be here today. He raised me in hiding in nearby villages, and we awaited the day Leonster would rise again. We thought that day had finally come, but then...

speaker: Seliph
text: ...We both took to the battlefield around the same time, did we not? By now practically all of Jugdral knows of King Blume's brutality. I sorely wish my army had made it here sooner and could've properly aided you. You have my deepest apologies, Prince Leif.

speaker: Leif
text: No, Lord Seliph. I'm the one who should be apologizing. Our failure was squarely my fault. However, this isn't over. I am the son of Quan, a man worthy of being dubbed a Knight of Njörun. I refuse to put to shame his legacy, and so I'll live on. I'll fight on, no matter the cost. To that end, Lord Seliph, my comrades and I would like to join your army. I may not have much of an army left, but what I do have is yours. May we serve you well in restoring honor to Grannvale.

speaker: Seliph
text: Thank you, Prince Leif. Often I have heard it said that our fathers were inseparable friends, bound together to the bitter end in both life and death. Not to mention, your mother, Queen Ethlyn, is also my aunt... Both of your parents gave their lives to support my father's cause... Prince Leif, you have my deepest, most heartfelt apologies for their sacrifice...

speaker: Leif
text: Thank you, but that isn't necessary. I am proud of my parents' sacrifice, and I've the utmost respect for Lord Sigurd. The only hatred I bear is for the true villains, Emperor Arvis and King Travant!

speaker: Seliph
text: As do I... Prince Leif, in the name of our late fathers' last wishes, I seek to restore peace and light to all of Jugdral. Please, join me in my cause!

speaker: Leif
text: Yes, sir! You have my blade as your own!

speaker: Myrmidon
text: Lord Bramsel has decreed that none shall pass this point for the time being. Move along.

speaker: Arthur
text: Excuse me, but... That pendant of yours...

speaker: Tine
text: Huh? It's... It's a memento of my mother...

speaker: Arthur
text: Really?! Then you're Tine! Oh, I've finally found you!

speaker: Tine
text: Er... Who are you?

speaker: Arthur
text: Here, maybe this'll clear things up. This pendant of mine's exactly the same as yours, and I've had it my whole life.

speaker: Tine
text: Y-you're right, but... What are you saying?

speaker: Arthur
text: See, decades ago, my mother was a warrior fighting in Sigurd's liberation army, and after the war she fled to Silesse with her children. When I was little, my mother and my newborn sister disappeared... I was left behind with nothing but this pendant. I only recently learned what really happened. It was King Blume of Alster. He abducted them. He took my family from me. The rumors I've heard all said Mother had died a while ago, but they also said my sister is still alive... That's you, Tine! I've finally found you, after all these years! I came all this way just to see you again...

speaker: Tine
text: I... I never even knew Blume did that to Mother... It makes sense, though... I can't remember much of Mother, but I know I never saw her smile or laugh... You're my brother... Oh... Sniff...

speaker: Arthur
text: I don't suppose you'd like to lay down your arms and join our army, Tine? We've still got so much to talk about.

speaker: Tine
text: Mm. Thank you, brother. I never did want to fight…

speaker: Tine
text: Um... Pardon me, sir...

speaker: Seliph
text: Hm? And who are you, ma'am?

speaker: Tine
text: I am Tine... Arthur’s sister...

speaker: Seliph
text: Ah, of course. I've been told your story, Tine.

speaker: Tine
text: Um... I'm sorry!

speaker: Seliph
text: You've nothing to apologize for, Tine. With the likes of King Blume for an uncle, I completely understand. You had no choice.

speaker: Tine
text: Are... are you forgiving me, sir?

speaker: Seliph
text: Certainly! There's no question that you're not our enemy, and it would be an honor to have you with us.

speaker: Tine
text: Wow... You're everything the stories say you are! I wish we couldn't met sooner...

speaker: Seliph
text: Heh... Thank you! Listen, Tine. I know fighting your own family is a painful prospect, so please, don't force yourself if you're at all uncomfortable.

speaker: Tine
text: Sir…

speaker: Finn
text: Ah! ...Pardon me, but who are you?

speaker: Larcei
text: Huh? I’m Larcei…

speaker: Finn
text: T-This cannot be…

speaker: Larcei
text: Hey, what’s your problem? You realize you’re staring at me, right?

speaker: Finn
text: Oh… My apologies, miss. It’s just you bear a striking resemblance to someone…

speaker: Larcei
text: Huh? I do…?

speaker: Finn
text: Yes… My apologies. This is a bit embarrassing, but you are the spitting image of a woman I loved long ago.

speaker: Larcei
text: Were you two a thing or what?

speaker: Finn
text: We were, for a time… But we parted during the war. I’ve been looking for her ever since…

speaker: Larcei
text: Oh… Sorry about that. What was her name?

speaker: Finn
text: You’re the only person I’ve met who matches her beauty. Her name was Ayra…

speaker: Larcei
text: Wait, Ayra?! ...A-are you kidding or what…

speaker: Finn
text: Ah! ...Pardon me, but who are you?

speaker: Lana
text: Oh! Er, my name is Lana… You’re Sir Finn, are you not?

speaker: Finn
text: Y-you are…

speaker: Lana
text: ...Er, is something wrong, sir? You keep staring at me…

speaker: Finn
text: Oh… My apologies, miss. It’s just you bear a striking resemblance to someone…

speaker: Lana
text: I… do?

speaker: Finn
text: Yes… My apologies. This is a bit embarrassing, but you are the spitting image of a woman I loved long ago.

speaker: Lana
text: Was she your wife?

speaker: Finn
text: She was, for a time… But we parted during the war. I’ve been looking for her ever since…

speaker: Lana
text: Oh… What a sad story. What was her name?

speaker: Finn
text: You’re the only person I’ve met to match her beauty. Her name was Aideen…

speaker: Lana
text: Aideen?! That’s… That’s my mother!

speaker: Finn
text: How are you faring, Nanna?

speaker: Nanna
text: I’m okay, Father. You don’t need to worry over me so much.

speaker: Finn
text: Heh, you’re getting as strong-willed and bold as your mother was. It’s almost like it’s twenty years ago and I’m talking to Lachesis again…

speaker: Nanna
text: I don’t get it, Father. If you loved Mother as much as you keep saying you did, how could you just let her run off by herself like that?!

speaker: Finn
text: Look, Nanna. I’m sorry, but her journey to Isaach is none of your business. That was a private matter between her and myself. I ask that you do not intrude.

speaker: Nanna
text: But-

speaker: Finn
text: I promise that you’ll understand someday, when you’re a bit older…

speaker: Ares
