text: I once heard a story about my parents... On a visit to Miletos, my father gifted my mother with the most stunning pearl tiara.

speaker: Nanna
text: Did he?

speaker: Leif
text: He did indeed, and someday... Someday, I'd love to do the same for you, Nanna.

speaker: Nanna
text: Oh, Lord Leif...

speaker: Leif
text: Heh, I suppose I'm getting a bit ahead of myself. We still have an empire to bring down before we do anything else, after all! The end of this blasted war is in sight, Nanna. Now, shall we?

speaker: Nanna
text: Of course, Lord Leif!

speaker: Shannan
text: You've grown so strong of late, Seliph! You really are your parents' son. There's nothing left for me to teach you.

speaker: Seliph
text: Thank you, Shannan... For everything. Any might I have springs from your teachings. To me, swordplay is every bit as natural as breathing, and I owe it all to you.

speaker: Shannan
text: Heh... You think so, do you...

speaker: Seliph
text: You look awfully weary, Shannan... Is something amiss? If only I could lend you my strength...

speaker: Shannan
text: Hey, come on! You needn't treat me like some old man. I'm as young and spry as ever, you know!

speaker: Seliph
text: Oh! My apologies, Shannan... That wasn't what I was-

speaker: Shannan
text: Heh, it's fine. ...Thanks anyway, Seliph. It heartens me to know that you care.

speaker: Faval
text: Wait a minute… I’ve never seen someone so frail hold their own out here like this. Aren’t you scared at all?

speaker: Lana
text: I won’t lie to you… I am. I really am. But I could never sit back and do nothing knowing all those children are still in peril.

speaker: Faval
text: Huh, so you’re fond of kids, then?

speaker: Lana
text: Oh, certainly! I love children. And from what I hear, you do as well! You’ve been looking after orphans, haven’t you, Faval? I think that’s just wonderful!

speaker: Faval
text: Er, don’t get too excited there… Patty dragged me into the whole “look after orphans” thing. Not the biggest fan myself.

speaker: Lana
text: Hee hee hee… You sound so sure! I’m not blind, you know. How, then, do you explain all the sobbing children who begged you to stay just as you left to join us? Why, they must all see you as some sort of father figure!

speaker: Faval
text: H-hey, stop it, will you? I… it’s just that… Look, I’ve got some things to go do, okay?

speaker: Lana
text: Heh! Oh, Faval…

speaker: Oifey
text: Look, sire! The territory of Chalphy awaits us just across the Miletos Strait.

speaker: Seliph
text: Chalphy... My father's fatherland... I can only imagine all the memories you must have of it, Oifey.

speaker: Oifey
text: Mm, of course. I don't think there's a single corner of Chalphy which I don't recall fondly... Lord Sigurd and Lady Ethlyn... Noish, Alec, and all of my other peers among the young knights of Chalphy... Every last face there was a friendly one...

speaker: Seliph
text: Hm... I can only imagine, Oifey. I've never so much as set foot in Chalphy, have I?

speaker: Oifey
text: Indeed, sire. You were born in Agustria, and raised in Silesse and Isaach. Come to think of it sire, you've never been anywhere near Grannvale till now.

speaker: Seliph
text: Quite the sorry excuse for a prince of Grannvale I make, wouldn't you say? It almost feels as if I've tricked the world.

speaker: Oifey
text: I know, sire, but I pray you understand. This is the will of your citizens, all long abused and stripped of power by the Empire. They've endured decades of suffering beyond compare at the Empire's hands, all in the hope of, one day, seeing the coming of their savior.

speaker: Seliph
text: This savior... Do they believe it to be me?

speaker: Oifey
text: They do. The common folk have long prayed for the second coming for the hero Sigurd. The folklore claims he comes once more in the form of a legendary child whom Sigurd begat with Empress Deirdre.

speaker: Seliph
text: A legendary child... It's terrifying to know that people have taken to seeing me as some sort of god, Oifey.

speaker: Oifey
text: Think of it as a product of the sheer brutality of the Empire's regime, sire. Look around you. We stand in a realm where children are snatched from their parents in droves, and all who resist are put to slaughter. No mere human could ever wreak such madness. A great evil lurks behind it all...

speaker: Seliph
text: Say, Oifey... I've been hearing tales that Emperor Arvis is the dark god itself. Where do you stand?

speaker: Oifey
text: I've heard the same from countless others in our travels, sire, but I doubt it.

speaker: Seliph
text: Then who could it be? Manfroy, perhaps?

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire... Whoever it may be, the dark god's return is fast approaching. We must hurry. Your people have come to revere you as a crusader destined to save them. The time to heed their call is upon us.

speaker: Seliph
text: Pardon me, Fee. Lewyn would like a word with you. If you need me, I'll be waiting over there.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Geez, Fee. I haven't seen anyone as stubborn as you since I last saw Erinys!

speaker: Lewyn
text: C'mon, there's no need to get angry! I'm here to apologize, okay? Ignoring you clearly wasn't the best idea I've ever had.

speaker: Fee
text: What kind of monster are you, Dad?! I... I could've sworn I was seeing things when you first popped up in Rivough! I hadn't been that happy in years, and... And seeing you again had me in tears... But then when I tried talking to you, you wouldn't so much as blink at me! Do you have any idea how it feels to be shunned by your own father, Dad?!

speaker: Lewyn
text: So you went about pretending you didn't notice me either? Is that it?

speaker: Fee
text: I figured, why should I bother if you're not gonna bother? I told myself I'd only talk to you if you took the initiative here.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Heh... Bratty little thing, aren't you...

speaker: Fee
text: EXCUSE ME?! Ohh, that does it! I'm not listening to another word of this! Maybe if she hadn't married such an awful man, Mom'd still be with us...

speaker: Lewyn
text: Look, Fee. I get it. I really messed things up with Erinys. But what happened is my business and hers. Nobody else's. You and Ced have no right to meddle!

speaker: Fee
text: Dad-

speaker: Lewyn
text: There's a war going on here, Fee, and that's the only thing you should be worrying about right now. Understood?

speaker: Seliph
text: Pardon me, Lene. Lewyn would like a word with you. If you need me, I'll be waiting over there.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Take care of yourself out here, Lene. There’d be no greater tragedy for humanity than seeing your lovely face scarred, huh?

speaker: Lene
text: Say, Lewyn… I, er, don’t suppose you ever knew my mom?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Hm? What makes you say that?

speaker: Lene
text: I dunno. I guess it seems like you know just about everything, Lewyn.

speaker: Lewyn
text: You want to know more about her, then?

speaker: Lene
text: Yep! And my dad too, if possible.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Lene… You’re your own wonderful person. You shouldn’t worry too much about who your parents were or what they were like. But I can tell you one thing: Your parents loved you so much, above all else… That will never change. As tragic as their parting with you was, they still watch over you… Even now.

speaker: Lene
text: Y’know, I think you’re right. All my life, even when I was little, I’ve always felt like someone’s been watching over me… That has to be Dad… I just know it! But why… If he’s still alive like this, why won’t he come out to see me?! I’ve been waiting all my life for him… I’m… I’m so lonely without him…

speaker: Lewyn
text: Lene…

speaker: Seliph
text: Pardon me, Tine. Lewyn would like a word with you. If you need anything from me, I’ll be waiting over there.

speaker: Lewyn
text: Say, Tine. Hilda was your aunt, right? I can only imagine how painful having to fight her was…

speaker: Tine
text: No, not really. Lady Hilda is a horrific woman…

speaker: Lewyn
text: She didn’t treat you well, did she?

speaker: Tine
text: Mm… Day after day, again and again, she kept on beating and abusing us. And she kept on accusing Mother of being a traitor…

speaker: Lewyn
text: Your mother… Tailtiu, right…

speaker: Tine
text: Yes… After the Battle of Belhalla, she and my brother, Arthur, fled to Silesse. I was born there soon after. I never knew my father. I think he must’ve died long time ago…

speaker: Lewyn
text: I see… Then you went to Alster, right?

speaker: Tine
text: King Blume and his minions came to Silesse one night… They dragged us away to Alster… Mother never left there alive…

speaker: Lewyn
text: I… You’ve had such a hard life…

speaker: Tine
text: Mm… Hilda hated Mother so much. I’ve never seen anything like it… Mother must’ve coped with so much, all to protect me from Hilda. She was always in tears, right till the end…

speaker: Lewyn
text: She… She did?

speaker: Tine
text: Lord Lewyn? Is… Is everything okay, sir?

speaker: Lewyn
text: Yeah. Why d’you ask?

speaker: Tine
text: It’s your eyes, sir… Are those tears?

speaker: Lewyn
text: I… No, it’s… It’s nothing. This is just a bit of sweat. I’m fine… I… I’m okay…

speaker: Cairpre
text: Are you hurt at all, Your Highness?

speaker: Altena
text: Ah, Cairpre. Thank you, but everything's fine. Don't forget to take care of yourself as well. You shouldn't do anything too risky.

speaker: Cairpre
text: Er... Say, Your Highness...

speaker: Altena
text: Is something wrong, Cairpre?

speaker: Cairpre
text: Your Highness, I want to cast a Ward spell on you.

speaker: Altena
text: Oh, right. You're concerned about my low resistance to magic, aren't you? Are you sure? I've heard that few spells endanger the caster as much as Ward does. Look, Cairpre. I'm honored, but I don't want you risking yourself for my sake.

speaker: Cairpre
text: But you've always been there to help me, Your Highness. You're the closest thing I've ever had to a mama. Please, Your Highness! All I want is to do anything I can to help you!

speaker: Altena
text: Oh, Cairpre... Very well. I can hardly refuse if it's so important to you, now, can I? All I ask is that you stop casting the spell the instant it puts you at any risk at all. Promise me this, Cairpre.

speaker: Cairpre
text: Okay! It's a promise, Your Highness. Don't worry, I won't let myself get hurt.

speaker: Altena
text: Thank you, Cairpre. Now, shall we? I'm ready when you are.

speaker: Cairpre
text: Right, I'm ready! ...Hear me, O great Saint Bragi. ...I implore of you! Bestow upon this woman your exalted power…

speaker: Seliph
text: Are you unharmed, Your Grace?

speaker: Palmarch
text: Lord Seliph! Ohh, bless you! We've awaited you for so long. I've done all I can to survive, all to ensure you receive your birthright. Here... Take it, milord.

speaker: Seliph
text: W... what is this?

speaker: Palmarch
text: It is the sacred relic of House Chalphy. The divine blade... Tyrfing.

speaker: Seliph
text: But... How could you have it, Your Grace?

speaker: Palmarch
text: My apologies, milord, but I cannot say. I swore an oath...

speaker: Seliph
text: I see... Fair enough, then. I couldn't possibly thank you enough, Your Grace. So this is Tyrfing, then... I've never felt power quite like this...

speaker: Palmarch
text: Milord, I beg of you... Please, retake Chalphy at once! Your subjects have endured for so long, in hope of one day seeing your return...

speaker: Seliph
text: Rest easy now, Your Grace. So long as I have Tyrfing in hand, we have nothing more to fear!
Seliph... Oh, Seliph...

speaker: Seliph
text: I-is somebody there?
Oh, Seliph... How you've grown...

speaker: Seliph
text: Could it be... M-Mother?! Mother! Is it truly you?

speaker: Deirdre
text: What a fine young man you've become... Bless Lewyn for all he's done to guide you this far... ...Seliph, never forget. Your friends... Your companions... You must always cherish them... You owe them so...

speaker: Seliph
text: ...Y-yes, Mother. I understand. Oh! I've defeated Emperor Arvis! At long last, Father has been avenged!

speaker: Deirdre
text: You did... But what of Julius and Julia...?

speaker: Seliph
text: I still don't know... Wait! Mother, how could you know of what happened to them?

speaker: Seliph
text: ...Mother?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Seliph.

speaker: Seliph
text: Who's there? Wait... Is... Is it you, Father?!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Listen, Seliph. You must stay humble, no matter what. Remember, your power alone was not what put an end to Arvis...

speaker: Seliph
text: What? How do you mean, Father?

speaker: Sigurd
text: You must learn the sorrow of the common man, Seliph, Your truth is not the reality of all. Unless you know their pain, these long years of war will have been for naught...

speaker: Seliph
text: F-Father! Come back... Please!

speaker: Deirdre
text: Seliph... Take care, my son...

speaker: Seliph
text: Oh... Mother…

speaker: Girl
text: You're the liberation army? Wow... You're all amazing!

speaker: Boy
text: Whoa, the liberators! You're the best!

speaker: Boy
text: Wait, you're a crusader? Really? Huh…

speaker: Girl
text: Ohh! You're a crusader... I was really scared there…

speaker: Boy
text: Huh? You're with the liberators?! Wow! You came for us after all!

speaker: Girl
text: Thank you for rescuing me! Thank you!

speaker: Hilda
text: Monsters! You murdered my father-in-law, my husband, and my son... Know their vengeance!

speaker: Hilda
text: Ohoho! Well, if it isn't Tine! I knew you'd come crawling back to me. You really are every bit the ingrate your dear mama was!

speaker: Tine
text: Hilda! You... What you did to Mother...

speaker: Hilda
text: Ahh, that takes me back! It's been so long since I've had as much fun as tormenting that eyesore you call "mama"... Ahahaha!

speaker: Tine
text: No! You... I won't forgive you...

speaker: Hilda
text: Why, if I didn't know better, I'd say that's the smart mouth of someone all grown up! What could a brat like you ever hope to do? Good thing you miss your mama. You're about to go join her in hell!

speaker: Hilda
text: Gah... This can't be happening! I can't stay here... I must retreat…

speaker: Morrigan
text: Behold. In your final moments, you will cower in fear of my dark sorcery!

speaker: Morrigan
text: Your Excellency... I beg your forgiveness…

speaker: Riddell
text: Thank you, rebels. It's been far too long since I've seen an honest battle!

speaker: Riddell
text: Nngh... So this is how the gods will my fate…

speaker: Zagam
text: Heh heh... You've been cursed with such a poor fate…

speaker: Zagam
text: Archbishop Manfroy... Please... forgive me…

speaker: Ishtar
text: It seems as if this game shall be mine, Lord Julius!

speaker: Ishtar
text: Nng! Why…

speaker: Julius
text: You've lost, have you? Hmph... We leave at once!

speaker: Julius
text: Hmhmhm... Look, Ishtar. Victory is mine!

speaker: Julius
text: I grow weary of this silly game.

speaker: Arvis
text: You poor wretches. You cannot even imagine the hell I'll visit upon you!

speaker: Arvis
text: Deirdre... ...Julia...

speaker: Seliph
text: You... Emperor Arvis! Why... Why did you betray my father...

speaker: Arvis
text: At long last... Seliph. I must commend your courage, boy. But courage cannot save you now. Not since your dear departed father have I seen such a pathetic worm... My flames shall purge you from this world!

speaker: Eldigan
text: You're doing a fine job, soldier. I leave the border's defenses to you.

speaker: Cavalier
text: Yes, milord!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Sigurd! It's been a long time. Pray tell, why do I find you suddenly occupying Evans? You couldn't possibly be declaring war on Verdane, could you?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Eldigan! Am I glad to see you. Listen. The Verdanites have abducted Lady Aideen of Jungby. They've made it amply clear that they don't plan on releasing her. Taking her back by force is our only option.

speaker: Eldigan
text: Ah, I see. That makes sense. Well, whatever you do, you cannot afford to leave Evans unattended. My fellow Agustrian lords have been of a rancorous sort of late... Ah, I know. I'll ensure they don't threaten you from behind.

speaker: Sigurd
text: I'm sorry to involve you in this as well. Say, Eldigan, once I'm done here, what do you say to a catch up? You, me, a fine bottle of wine... Just like old times.

speaker: Eldigan
text: Mm. I'm looking forward to it. I trust I'll see you later, then. May luck be with you this day, Sigurd!

speaker: Kinbois
text: Listen up, Ayra! You know the deal. While I'm out, you guard the palace, right up to your very last breath. Remember, first sign of funny business, and it's the brat's head.

speaker: Shannan
text: Ayra! Ayra, I'll be alright! Don't give in to these thugs! Don't let 'em boss you around!

speaker: Ayra
text: Shannan... Look, Kinbois, you have my word. So long as you leave Shannan alone, you'll have no trouble. But I do wonder if, once this battle is over, you actually plan to return him to me.

speaker: Kinbois
text: Ahahahaha! You got nothing to worry about. If we get Evans back, you get him back.

speaker: Ayra
text: I understand. But be warned, Kinbois: if you break your promise, you'll deeply regret it. Cross me, and I will pursue you to the very depths of the inferno itself, till I take your head. Remember this well!

speaker: Kinbois
text: Wh-whoa, settle down there! I don't believe it... Such a cute face, but you only use it to spew bile like that! I'm not about to make an enemy outta someone with a sword arm as fine as yours. I can promise you that.

speaker: Ayra
text: Shannan, sit tight. Be patient for just a bit longer.

speaker: Shannan
text: Ayra, no! Don't do it! Don't go! AYRA!!

speaker: Kinbois
text: Feh... Right, boys, we're moving out! We're taking back Evans!

speaker: Jamke
text: Come on, Aideen! Take the brat and get out of here, and quickly! You need to get as far away as you can before Gandolf finds out!

speaker: Aideen
text: Pardon me, Prince Jamke, but are you not joining us?

speaker: Jamke
text: No. I won't stand for my brothers' vile ways but I just won't betray my father, either. I'm going back to the capital. I'm going to try, one more time, to convince my father.

speaker: Aideen
text: You're right... We must do all we can to end this war as soon as possible. Prince Jamke, I would sooner not burden you alone, but you are our only hope to persuade King Batur to end this.

speaker: Dew
text: Aideeeeeeen! C'mon, hurry up! We're still in serious danger here. If they catch me this time, then Gandolf'll rip my tongue out for sure!

speaker: Jamke
text: Dew, you're a thief. You got caught in the act. Any tongue rippings you get are your own fault. If Aideen hadn't insisted on letting you go too, you'd still be sitting in chains. Now, what did you promise to do?

speaker: Dew
text: I know, I know. I promised Aideen, too. I'm washin' my hands of thievin' from now on. Can I go now?

speaker: Jamke
text: I'll take your word for it. Now, go already!

speaker: Jamke
text: Aideen... May we meet again.

speaker: Gandolf
text: What?! Jamke let the broad go and went scurrying back to the capital? Gah! Damn my rat of a brother! Boys! We'er taking the wench and the brat back! If they put up a fight, kill 'em if you have to!

speaker: Gandolf
text: Oi, oi, oi! What do you lot think you’re doing out there!? The rest of you, get out there and fight! Now! Don’t let them touch the castle!

speaker: Ayra
text: So it's finally time... Woe be to all who cross me!

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire, we've found this young boy in the dungeon.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What's the matter? Why are silent? I want to know why you were held here.

speaker: Shannan
text: You're not one of Kinbois lot... Are you?

speaker: Sigurd
text: We've dealt with Kinbois. There's nothing to be afraid of anymore...

speaker: Shannan
text: Oh! So Ayra doesn't have to keep fighting! My Auntie Ayra was forced to fight 'cause Kinbois had me! Please! You've got to help her!

speaker: Sigurd
text: That swordswoman? Huh. I thought there was something amiss about her... Very well! I'll let her know that you're safe. Now, what's your name?

speaker: Shannan
text: Shannan. ...I'm Shannan, the prince of Isaach...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Isaach's prince, you say... I can barely begin to imagine what you've been through, Shannan. For now, though, you're welcome to stay with our army. Don't worry. One day, you'll make it home. I'll do all I can to ensure that.

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire, we've found this young boy in the dungeon.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Who are you? What's your name?

speaker: Shannan
text: I-I'm Shannan... Prince Shannan of Isaach... You're not one of Kinbois's lot... Are you?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Isaach's prince?! ...Er, forgive me. I am Sigurd, a paladin of Grannvale. We've defeated Prince Kinbois. You're safe now.

speaker: Shannan
text: Really?! Then Ayra doesn’t have to fight anymore! My Aunt Ayra was forced to fight ‘cause Kinbois had me! Come on, we gotta tell her!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Ayra? That swordswoman out there? ...Oh. Oh no...

speaker: Shannan
text: It... It can't be... She's dead? ...You killed Aunt Ayra?!

speaker: Sigurd
text: I'm so sorry, Shannan... If I had known, I would’ve done all I could to help her...

speaker: Shannan
text: Ayra...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Oifey, could you take care of Shannan for a while? Try to help him calm down a bit.

speaker: Oifey
text: Pardon me, sire, but we're currently at war with Isaach. If we're going to harbor its prince, shouldn't we inform the king?

speaker: Sigurd
text: He's a child, Oifey. That war has nothing to do with him. I'll find a way to get him home safely, but for now, we need to look after him.

speaker: Oifey
text: Understood, sire.

speaker: Oifey
text: Just as I thought... Lord Sigurd really is such a kind man…

speaker: Ayra
text: Genoa has fallen to Grannvale?! No! I... I must get to Shannan!

speaker: Elliot
text: Tch. Does Grannvale really think it can just waltz into Verdane with such a tiny force? How adorable. Men, here's our chance. Evans is ripe for the plucking, then it's straight for the Grannvale border!

speaker: Cavalier
text: Is that... No! That's the Heirhein army! Lord Eldigan won't like this…

speaker: Ayra
text: Shannan isn’t here!? No… The Grannvalians must have him. Those fiends…They won’t live to regret it!

speaker: Eldigan
text: What's this? Heirhein's army is marching on Evans?! Ugh... I should've known Elliot just couldn't keep his nose out of this. Take care of the castle, Lachesis. Sigurd is in dire need of my help.

speaker: Lachesis
text: Of course, brother. Please, do all you can to help Sir Sigurd.

speaker: Eldigan
text: Right! Cross Knights, move out! Our foe is the Heirhein army. I don't expect a challenge, but stay alert nonetheless!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Elliot! Ambushing them like a common thief, are you? A cowardly act, ill befitting the honor of a knight! Withdraw immediately, or I will take action. We both know you're no match for me.

speaker: Elliot
text: What's this? Eldigan?! I should've known you would side with Grannvale!

speaker: Eldigan
text: In doing this you are crossing not just Grannvale, nor me, but your very liege! We bow to the reverent King Imca, who desires only peace with Grannvale. Would you truly cross His Majesty?

speaker: Elliot
text: You fool! Only you would still seriously heed that senile old fool's word. The lords of Agustria are united against both Grannvale and any peace with them!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Wrong, for I will not stand with you! Agustria cannot afford the crippling tolls of war, and nor can Grannvale. Our past stands as a testament to this. Learn well, Elliot: we, the nobility, know not the suffering brought by war. War cripples only the powerless, our subjects. I will not abide your lust for glory at the expense of our people!

speaker: Elliot
text: A pretty little speech, but that won't save you now. I knew all along: you and I were always fated to clash, Eldigan! Today, we settle this, once and for all! Men, the enemy is now House Nordion! I want Eldigan's head on a platter!

speaker: Eldigan
text: Elliot has fled? Very well. Leave him to lick his wounds. We're done here. Withdraw!

speaker: Deirdre
text: N-no! Please, let go of me!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Heh heh... What's the matter? C'mon, I'm just askin' for a little date.

speaker: Deirdre
text: I need to go home, sir. I ask of you, please, pay me no mind!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Shaddup! Keep up your yappin' and you'll regret it!

speaker: Sigurd
text: What's going on here? Let the girl go.

speaker: Ruffian
text: What's your problem!? This ones- ...Urgh! You're not that Grannvale paladin, are you?

speaker: Sigurd
text: You understand the situation? Then be on your way. There are none I loath more than your kind. The girl has given you her answer. Now, leave her be and get out of my sight!

speaker: Ruffian
text: Yeah... Yeah, got it... My bad, missy. I was just teasin', is all. Sorry. I'll be off now...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Are you alright?

speaker: Deirdre
text: Y-yes... Thank you, Sir Sigurd.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm? You know of me?

speaker: Deirdre
text: Yes. I met a woman named Aideen not long ago in this castle, and...

speaker: Sigurd
text: She spoke of me.

speaker: Deirdre
text: She did. I knew from the moment I laid eyes on you: You are in every way the man I had imagined...

speaker: Sigurd
text: May I... ask for your name?

speaker: Deirdre
text: ...I'm sorry, but... ...I... I must go.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Wait! Please, I just want to talk for a little longer--

speaker: Deirdre
text: ...I am truly sorry. I am glad we could meet, even once...

speaker: Sigurd
text: What? What do you mean? Please, wait! ...Ah.

speaker: Old Man
text: Lord Sigurd, is it? What's the matter?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Oh... You must be the town elder! That woman who ran off just now... Do you know who she is?

speaker: Old Man
text: Ahh, of course. That woman is called Deirdre. She is a priestess of the Spirit Forest.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre... She's beautiful...

speaker: Old Man
text: Ohoho, even a refined man like you can't resist being charmed by her ilk! Could it be love at first sight? Hoho...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Sir, please. Don't tease me. And yet... I've never seen anybody so beautiful before. I... I need to see her again.

speaker: Old Man
text: Alas, sir, for it cannot be so. The folk of the Spirit Forest staunchly refuse to partake in the world beyond their woods. Furthermore, that girl and members of her clan are forbidden from ever liaising with men. Village lore dictates that should this ever happen, calamity would befall the world. You have no choice, sir. Resign yourself of that girl.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What superstitious nonsense! That poor girl... Deirdre... we must meet again.

speaker: Lex
text: Ugh, dammit! I dropped my axe!

speaker: Woman
text: What you dropped... Was it this golden axe? Or perhaps, this silver axe?

speaker: Lex
text: Oh, no. My axe isn't anything as fine as those two. It's just a plain old iron axe.

speaker: Woman
text: Such an honest person... As a reward... I present you with this brave axe... Farewell, Lord Lex...

speaker: Lex
text: Er…

speaker: Jamke
text: Father, this is absurd! Why do you still refuse to listen to me? My brothers already have fallen, and it's only a matter of time before they come for the capital as well. The Grannvale commander, Sir Sigurd, is a good man. Please, end the war while you still can!

speaker: Batur
text: I... allowed Gandolf's raid only because I'd been told that Grannvale would surely come to invade us first. Never did I intend for a war like this.

speaker: Jamke
text: It was that sorcerer, Sandima, who told you that, wasn't it? You, Kinbois, and Gandolf trusted him too readily. You've all been deceived!

speaker: Sandima
text: Now, now, Prince Jamke. That's enough of that. Your duty as prince is to lead your men into the fray. Dawdling in a place like this would be deeply troublesome of you.

speaker: Jamke
text: Argh! Damn you, Sandima!

speaker: Batur
text: That's enough, Jamke. Listen to Sandima. Go. Lead your men into the fray.

speaker: Jamke
text: Father! ...Very well. If you won't change your mind, even now, then... I'll see this through as well. But be warned. Should I return victorious, Sandima, I'll allow you to live no longer!

speaker: Batur
text: Sandima... Perhaps, for all this time, you may not have been entirely forthright with me. You did assure me that Grannvale hungers to claim our land, and yet...

speaker: Sandima
text: Feh... And just what are you saying now? To think, I believed that your Verdanites would be of use... You truly are naught but savages. You are worthless. Completely and utterly worthless! And from now on, your army is mine to command!

speaker: Batur
text: What?! No, stay back! Back, I- -Guhh...

speaker: Sandima
text: Feh... Feeble-minded old fool.

speaker: Manfroy
text: So, you've put an end to the king, Sandima... Do you expect that the Verdanite army will still obey your command?

speaker: Sandima
text: Oh, Archbishop Manfroy! How long have you been here, Your Eminence? The army is of no concern at all. They need only know that the king has fallen ill.

speaker: Manfroy
text: Hrm, I see... And what of the situation here? Does the plan progress?

speaker: Sandima
text: My sincerest apologies, Your Excellency. That Grannvalian... Sigurd, or something, has proven to be an unexpected obstacle to the invasion.

speaker: Manfroy
text: Hrm... And what of the search for the Loptrian scion? Have you found Sigyn's daughter?

speaker: Sandima
text: Er... No, not yet...

speaker: Manfroy
text: Imbecile! After all of the pains I have gone to, to locate the boy... The son of Sigyn is still in Belhalla, but he's worthless without the female. Listen well. Sigyn was an heir of Prince Maira, brother of an emperor of the old Loptyr Empire. Sigyn alone in this era inherited the sacred blood of the dark lord. That woman broke the commandment that Maira placed upon his heirs and bore two children. Do you know what this means?

speaker: Sandima
text: Yes, Your Eminence. When the blood of the two heir intersects, the second coming of the dark lord, Loptyr, will be upon us.

speaker: Manfroy
text: Precisely, and so too shall we, descendants of the Loptyr Empire, return to this world. You know as well as I, Sandima, how heavily our fates depend upon the resurrection of the dark lord. You know well our order's centuries of exile, hidden deep within the Aed Desert. You know well the abuses... The famines... How we were sustained only by dreaming of the day when the Empire will rise again. And at long last, that day is upon us.

speaker: Sandima
text: Understood, Your Eminence. If I must surrender my life to ensure that the plan is realized, I will do it gladly!

speaker: Deirdre
text: Wait... Lord Sigurd...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm? Is that... Deirdre! Ah! So this must be your Spirit Forest. Thank the gods! For a moment I thought that I might never see you again.

speaker: Deirdre
text: Milord, listen. The dark priest Sandima guards Castle Verdane with his wicked magic. You must go no further. You would surely be killed. Please, you mustn't go...

speaker: Sigurd
text: But I mustn't place my men in even greater danger, either. I have no choice but to go.

speaker: Deirdre
text: ...I see. Then I will go with you.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Deirdre
text: This is called a Silence staff. So long as my own power is enough to pierce his magical resistances, it will seal his magic away. Trust me, milord. I'll ensure his dark spells never harm anyone ever again.

speaker: Sigurd
text: I'd never imagined that you'd have such power... But why... Why are you helping me?

speaker: Deirdre
text: ...I tried to forget you all I could, but it was all in vain. ...I no longer know what I should do...

speaker: Sigurd
text: What is it you're afraid of, Deirdre? I don't understand. But if you and I feel the same way, then surely we've nothing to fear. I... I love you, Deirdre…

speaker: Deirdre
text: I heard of Sandima's defeat. I was afraid that he'd find me... He was a dark priest from a shadowy cult, sent to Verdane to find me.

speaker: Sigurd
text: A... shadowy cult? What in the world do you mean?

speaker: Deirdre
text: I don't know much of it myself. All I know comes from the last words of the old woman who raised me. Somewhere in this world, she said, there lies an ancient order dedicated to the ancient dark god, Loptyr. So devout are they, it is said that they plot to resurrect their once-fallen god.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Yes, I've heard those rumors myself. But why is this cult after you?

speaker: Deirdre
text: The dark god slumbers within my very blood... Through me, they have some way of reviving Loptous. This is why she told me on her deathbed: I must never be found, she said. I must never mingle with men...

speaker: Sigurd
text: I see... So that's why you kept running away from me.

speaker: Deirdre
text: I was afraid of falling in love. I did all I could to forget you, but... Love found me still. I couldn't do it... I couldn't bear to lose you. I... no longer know what I should do...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre... I know you must fear where your destiny might lead. But nothing will come of living in fear. I will protect you. Come what may, I will protect you. Deirdre, if you and I feel the same way, then we've nothing to fear. O gods above, should our love be a sin, then deliver punishment unto me alone! I swear this day: Even should my body be rendered and rent, no regrets will ever haunt me. All I ask, O gods... Protect my beloved Deirdre in my stead, for all eternity!

speaker: Deirdre
text: Ahh... Milord…

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre?! Oh, thank the gods! You’re alright!

speaker: Deirdre
text: Mm. The enemy captured and imprisoned me, but I knew… I knew you would come for me, no matter what.

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire, we've found a casualty in the palace. It's... it's King Batur himself. By the look of it, he's well beyond help.

speaker: Sigurd
text: King Batur! Are you alright? Please, come on... you can make it!

speaker: Batur
text: Hnnh... Lord... Sigurd? I am so sorry for doing all this to you... I let Sandima... lead me astray... He... he abused my trust... and won over my sons... all to seize control of Verdane for himself...

speaker: Sigurd
text: I understand, Your Highness, but you need to rest now. Please, you mustn't stress yourself further.

speaker: Batur
text: No... It's too late for me... Heed my word, Sigurd, for there is one final thing I must tell you... The misery here... the grief spreading across Jugdral... it is all the will of the dark priesthood... They blight our world from the shadows, all in the name of the revival of their dark god, Loptyr... Sandima... was one of them... He twisted us to war with Grannvale... for the sake of the cult's madness. The... the dark priests... they infect every corner of our world... Sigurd... Stay vigilant, lest you be tricked too! I... I failed the people of Verdane... Sigurd, I beg you... Make this right... Protect... my... people...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Oh... Your Highness... The dark priesthood? What in the blazes is happening...?

speaker: Woman
text: This village is part of the holdings of Prince Kinbois, lord of Genoa. He's as dreadful as they come! Barely a month goes by without him settin' his army on us. It's terrifyin'! King Batur, his father, used to do such a fine job of keepin' him in check. I can hardly imagine what's goin' on... Anyway, glad you stopped by!

speaker: Woman
text: King Batur is as gentle as they come. Normally, at least, leading a war like this is the last thing he'd ever do. Mark my words: this is all the doing of Sandima, his sorcerous advisor. I can just feel it. Eking out a living here's grown tougher and tougher since the day that man arrived, and save for the youngest son, Jamke, both king and country are at his very whim. Please, I beg you... Save our country! Bring back the Verdane that once was!

speaker: Old Man
text: Just t'the north a here is this mighty woodland. S'called the Spirit Forest. Once upon a time, I lived there too, in this li'l hamlet deep within. Th' village is home to the last kin o' the dark one of old, Loptyr. They say it all started with Saint Maira, exiled by the empire for darin' to sympathize with mortal men. In my day, there was this gorgeous girl livin' there called Sigyn, the last heir o' Loptyr's bloodline, she was. She lived 'er life under close guard, the villagers wary o' lettin' the blood o' Loptyr loose into th' world. Alas, Sigyn grew weary o' the tedious forest life an' she left it all behind, breaking ancient commandments. A couple o' years later, she came back, 'cept now she was pregnant. Never said who the father was, mind. Before long Sigyn died, even as she gave birth t' her daughter. From what I 'eard, the hamlet's old prophet took 'er in and raised the girl as 'er own. If the little girl's still alive, she'd 'ave to be 'bout seventeen or eighteen by now...

speaker: Quan
text: Finn, this will likely be a very long battle. My apologies for bringing you into it.

speaker: Finn
text: I am but your humble servant, milord. I would go anywhere, should my master will it.

speaker: Quan
text: Thank you, Finn.

speaker: Finn
text: Even so, I am but a page... It honors me to have your confidence, but I doubt I'll be of much use to you.

speaker: Quan
text: Is that so? In that case, what better time than now is there for a spot of hands-on training? Draw, Finn!

speaker: Finn
text: Yes, sir!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Aideen? Thank goodness you're okay!

speaker: Aideen
text: Lord Sigurd! So you came to my aid, did you? Please accept my apologies. I've put the people of Chalphy through nothing but danger...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Don't worry about it. Everyone will be glad to know that you're safe. You've nothing to worry about anymore. The road back to Jungby is secure for you, when you're ready.

speaker: Aideen
text: No, I wish to remain here. Injuries are inevitable in war. As a humble servant to the gods, it is my duty to stay here and aid your wounded.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Say, Aideen... As I recall, you declined to pursue a knighthood and instead joined the clergy. Am I right? I shouldn't be surprised, knowing how easily people warm to you, and you them. I'd do well to learn from your example!

speaker: Aideen
text: Thank you, Lord Sigurd, but that isn't entirely true. Initially, I sought priesthood in a bid to help me find my sister. Even now, I still believe this is the answer I seek.

speaker: Sigurd
text: You mean Bridget... I'd heard that she went missing as a child. So all this time, Aideen, you've been praying for her sake, haven't you?

speaker: Aideen
text: Yes. I know we'll meet someday. No matter what happens, I must give her this: her sacred birthright, the bow Yewfelle!

speaker: Azelle
text: Ah, Lady Aideen! You're safe... thank the gods...

speaker: Aideen
text: Lord Azelle? Have you been fighting for Jungby as well?

speaker: Azelle
text: When the news of your abduction reached us, the thought of you in danger while I just sat at home was unbearable! I came to Jungby as quickly as I could.

speaker: Aideen
text: Hold on. You are the younger brother of Lord Arvis of Velthomer, are you not? Did he allow you to come?

speaker: Azelle
text: No, I... I came without his consent. And he certainly won't be pleased.

speaker: Aideen
text: Why would you do something so reckless, then? I thought you abhorred violence.

speaker: Azelle
text: Because I... er, well...

speaker: Aideen
text: Oh? What is it, Azelle?

speaker: Azelle
text: It's... It's nothing... never mind.

speaker: Midir
text: Milady? You... you're safe! Ahh... thank the gods! I'm so sorry I failed to protect you. Please, forgive me...

speaker: Aideen
text: The important part is that you're safe as well, Midir. Please, don't worry about it. You gave your all to protect me, and I couldn't thank you enough for that, even if you didn't succeed. For now I'd like you to remain with Sigurd. He could use your strength.

speaker: Midir
text: Certainly, milady. He's done so much for me, for you, and for all of Jungby. I'll do all I can to return his kindness.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Aideen, are you okay? When I heard you'd been abducted, I was so worried!

speaker: Aideen
text: You came to fight for me as well, Ethlyn? Thank you... I'm sorry for your trouble. It's difficult to convey my thanks, but please, accept this staff. I think you'll have more use for it than me.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Is this... a Return staff?! Oh, thank you, Aideen! I'll put it to good use to help us all.

speaker: Dew
text: Hey! Miss Aideen! I got something good to give you. Look, I picked up this odd cane. It won't do much good if I just hold onto it, will it?

speaker: Aideen
text: Oh? This is a Warp staff. Where did you find it, Dew?

speaker: Dew
text: Oh... er... I... I found it just over there! Yeah! That's right. Weird, isn't it? I betcha one of the gods left it over there. Juuuuust for you!

speaker: Aideen
text: Oh, Dew... Having a staff like this ought to be a great help for everybody. Thank you. I'll cherish it.

speaker: Quan
text: Princess Ayra of Isaach, I presume? I heard your story from Sigurd. I am Quan of Leonster.

speaker: Ayra
text: A pleasure.

speaker: Quan
text: I'd hate to press you for information so soon, but there's something I'd like to know. Why did Isaach attack Darna in the first place? Surely you knew doing so would invoke the wrath of Grannvale. That King Mananan would commit such a reckless act... The very idea defies belief.

speaker: Ayra
text: You knew my father, Sir Quan?!

speaker: Quan
text: I'm afraid I never had the chance to meet him. However, my father knows him well. He always had only the utmost praise for him. He also speaks fondly of your brother, Prince Mariccle. He's always said he is a fine young man.

speaker: Ayra
text: Is that so? It heartens me to hear it. Without a doubt, my father and Mariccle were admirable men. Never would they condone such an assault on a defenseless city. In the matter of Darna, the patriarch of Rivough acted alone and without our consent...

speaker: Quan
text: I beg your pardon?! Why haven't the Grannvalians heard this? Surely if Prince Kurth knew the truth, he would refuse to continue the war.

speaker: Ayra
text: So, too, thought my father. Once he executed the Rivough patriarch, he departed for the Grannvale front, head in tow, to negotiate with them. But...

speaker: Quan
text: ...Yes?

speaker: Ayra
text: My father, the king... He was assassinated on the way. Once word of this returned to Isaach, the people were utterly incensed. Mariccle set out, leading our entire army, seeking vengeance against Grannvale.

speaker: Quan
text: Something is amiss here. The murder of a king who seeks peace talks certainly isn't like Prince Kurth, either. Have you told Sigurd of this as well?

speaker: Ayra
text: No. Lord Sigurd carries enough of a burden as it is. It's too late for my brother...

speaker: Quan
text: Prince Mariccle was resigned to his death when he engaged Grannvale, wasn't he...

speaker: Ayra
text: My brother believed to the last that Isaach's hope for the future rests in Shannan, his son. My role is to protect Shannan, and with him, the promise of Isaach's liberty...

speaker: Quan
text: I see. Thank you for telling me, Princess Ayra. Someday, the world will know this truth, and till that day comes, you mustn't give in. I will do all I can to help you.

speaker: Ayra
text: Thank you, Sir Quan.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hold, Lady Ayra! Prince Shannan is safe with us! You needn't keep fighting.

speaker: Ayra
text: What? You saved Shannan? Do you speak the truth?!

speaker: Sigurd
text: I do. Prince Shannan told me everything: that you're the daughter of the late Isaachian king. Listen. You detest Grannvalians. You've made your hostility perfectly clear. But you can't neglect your duty to the prince. You can't afford to waste your life now, not on a battle as senseless as this.

speaker: Ayra
text: My brother, the crown prince, entrusted Shannan to my care knowing that his death was inevitable. You're right. After all this time, I refuse to die for Verdane's sake. Until I've seen Shannan rise to the Isaachian throne, my life is not mine to forfeit to such dogs.

speaker: Sigurd
text: I will aid you all I can, if you lower your sword. On my honor as the heir of Baldr the Crusader, I swear I will not betray you.

speaker: Ayra
text: Very well. I'll place my trust in you, as well... Such is the way of the warriors of Isaach. For now, I pledge my blade in your service. However, this does not change that Grannvale is my foe. Beware, for if one day that includes you... I will not hesitate.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Mm, war can be truly cruel. Ayra, Isaachian warrior... I pray that day never comes.

speaker: Aideen
text: Hold, Prince Jamke!

speaker: Jamke
text: Aideen!? What are you doing here?

speaker: Aideen
text: You said you would persuade your father, yet instead you've taken to the field yourself. What is the matter with you?

speaker: Jamke
text: My father is a changed man. My words can no longer reach him... ...It all started when that sorcerer, Sandima, arrived. My entire family now obeys his every word.

speaker: Aideen
text: This is why I ask... Why have you taken to the field? Please, Jamke. Join us. Let's go to Verdane together. We can reason with the king, one more time. We can put an end to this war! Lord Sigurd has no interest in invading Verdane. He fought only to rescue me. Please listen, Jamke. Please... I beg of you.

speaker: Jamke
text: Fine... If you're willing to go so far, then I'll stain my name with treason. But it must be understood that I won't let anyone lay a finger on my father.

speaker: Aideen
text: Yes, I will promise you that. Thank you, Jamke. You truly are a good person.

speaker: Jamke
text: Aideen…

speaker: Kinbois
text: Pointing your little stick at me? That's precious, that is! I'll cave your head right in!

speaker: Kinbois
text: No… urgh…

speaker: Gandolf
text: Oh, come on! First my woman flees, and now this?! Damn my rotten luck!

speaker: Gandolf
text: And what are you supposed to be? You've got nerve, brat!

speaker: Azelle
text: So you're Gandolf... How dare you harm Aideen!

speaker: Gandolf
text: You're that knight from earlier?! Ugh, I don't believe this... What are you doing still alive?

speaker: Midir
text: Prepare yourself, Gandolf? I'll never forgive you!

speaker: Gandolf
text: N-no... This can't be... Guh…

speaker: Sandima
text: Kehehehehe... Learn to fear my dark magic.

speaker: Sandima
text: Archbishop Manfroy... F-forgive me…

speaker: Elliot
text: Damn you, Eldigan, and your little good-guy act! Your grudge against me ends, here and now!

speaker: Elliot
text: Oof... Men, retreat! Mark my words, Eldigan! This isn't over!

speaker: Sandima
text: You are too late, Jamke. Your father has already passed on.

speaker: Jamke
text: What?! Sandima! You... You're MINE!!

speaker: Sandima
text: What's this? A priestess, are you? Could it be... Might you be Deirdre... The cursed maiden…

speaker: Ayra
text: You stand between me and Shannan's future... Farewell!

speaker: Ayra
text: Shannan... I've failed you…

speaker: Jamke
text: I don't want to hurt you! Begone from this land at once!

speaker: Jamke
text: No... Father…

speaker: Byron
text: Nngh... Sigurd... ...No, I mustn't die yet... No... Not until the exalted blade is in your hands…

speaker: Slayder
text: Milord, we've sighted the fugitive Duke Byron. We caught him resting, but he slipped away. It seems as if he plans to escape to Silesse.

speaker: Langbalt
text: What?! You simpleton! Get out there and hunt him down, immediately! My ambush may have put an end to Chalphy's paladin brigade, the Grünritter, but the survival of Byron alone leaves that utterly meaningless!

speaker: Slayder
text: Y-yes, sir... But you see, milord, Byron is still gravely wounded. Surely, he has very little time left...

speaker: Langbalt
text: I've never heard such naïve drivel! Byron may not be long for this world, but he's determined to get that sword, Tyrfing, to his son with the very last of his strength. Do you not understand the threat that Sigurd would pose to us, should he get his hands on that damnable sword? Move out and kill Byron, immediately!

speaker: Slayder
text: Y-yes, sir! Consider it done!

speaker: Langbalt
text: For that matter, where in blazes is Danan with those reinforcements?! For the gods' sake, he's leading the elite Grau Ritter brigade! How could it take him so long to put down that Isaachian resistance?! First Lex, and now Danan... Why must both of my sons be so worthless?!

speaker: André
text: Come now, Lord Langbalt, sir! Don't worry about a thing. After all, you've still got the Beige Ritter and I on your side.

speaker: Langbalt
text: I suppose you're right, André. Be sure that your men are ready to join the fray at a moment's notice.

speaker: André
text: Heh. It would be my pleasure, sir…

speaker: Langbalt
text: Damn that insolent worm. To think he isn't even the slightest bit remorseful for slaying his own father! Duke Ring... May you be at peace…

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire! We've sighted a lone knight to our east, who appears to be headed our way.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm? Is he an enemy?

speaker: Oifey
text: I don't believe so. The Lubeck occupation seems to be pursuing him, so they're most likely not with them.

speaker: Sigurd
text: I see. Let's give them a hand. We'll be clashing with Langbalt's army sooner or later, so why not make the first move? Move out! Our target is their front lines. Today's victory hinges on this first strike!

speaker: Arden
text: Heh, who knew? Even I’ve got myself a wife and kids! Certainly can’t go dying now, not without leaving anything behind for them… Hm? What’s this tatty little book doing here? That’s odd… Nothing in this thing but complete gibberish. Wh- Ack! ...mnnnurraaaaagh! Whoa! What’s this feeling?! Everything’s looking, feeling, and sounding so much clearer now!

speaker: Azmur
text: Lord Arvis... Are Sigurd and his party truly on the march to our holy capital?

speaker: Arvis
text: Indeed, but we've no cause for alarm. Duke Langbalt and his army stands ready at Lubeck. It is only a matter of time before their insurrection is suppressed.

speaker: Azmur
text: Even so... Even now, it is almost beyond belief, is it not? That Lord Byron would slay Kurth... Or that Sigurd would incite a rebellion...

speaker: Arvis
text: Your Majesty, if I may explain once more... Lord Byron was plotting against the crown in concert with the late Lord Ring of Jungby. His Highness fell afoul of their assault, an act to which our very own Dukes Reptor and Langbalt bore witness. His Highness learned of their schemes to seize the throne from the royal family too late, and pair for it with his life. Naturally, Lord Sigurd had a hand in his father's revolt. What clearer proof is there than how he still harbors an enemy, the Isaachian prince? There is no question. Their treason against the state is grave. I, too, feel this pain as my own, having lost not only a prince but a father-in-law... And in the name of my beloved wife, Princess Deirdre, I will never allow Sigurd's traitorous rampage to stand! Even if Duke Langbalt fails to defeat him, that is not the end! The elite fire mages of House Velthomer, the Rot Ritter, stand ready to suppress this rebellion, once and for all!

speaker: Azmur
text: I see... If you say it is so, then perhaps... Perhaps this could never have been avoided... Arvis, about... Cough! About Deirdre...

speaker: Deirdre
text: Oh, Grandfather! Are you sure you feel all right? Please, you mustn't stress yourself! Come, lie down.

speaker: Azmur
text: Ah... Deirdre. Bless you... You truly are a sweet child. Even if I have little time left, you give me hope for Grannvale's future... I can scarcely imagine when Kurth would have had as fine a daughter as you... But there is no doubt in my mind. None outside the royal House Belhalla possess the same Brand that graces your brow. Whence did you come, my dear? Where in the world have you been all along...

speaker: Deirdre
text: I'm so sorry, Grandfather... I simply don't remember. Try as I may, I cannot recall even a single thing...

speaker: Azmur
text: Ah, forgive me, my dear... I know you have suffered more and long than any of us.

speaker: Arvis
text: From the moment I found her lost in the castle grounds, it was clear she had no memory of her past. All she knew was her own name. The rest of her past is lost to her. At first I sought only to aid her out of sympathy, as any decent man would do, but before long love took root within me... With all due respect, Deirdre, not once did I suspect that you could possibly be the daughter of our late Prince Kurth.

speaker: Azmur
text: I remember well the day you introduce her as the woman you wished to marry... I simply could not believe what I saw! At first sight... I knew, perhaps as only family can. Precisely as I thought, beneath your circlet lies the Brand of Naga. Lord Arvis, I trust you understand. Only a full-blooded heir to Saint Heim can rightfully wield the Book of Naga and release its true holy power. And the power of Naga is the only power able to oppose the dark lord, Loptyr.

speaker: Arvis
text: I am well aware of the legend, sire.

speaker: Azmur
text: The holy lineage of our lord Naga and Saint Heim must never perish! Deirdre... You must bear a son with all due haste! And should your son be so fortunate as to inherit Naga's power... He shall be the Prince of Grannvale, and shall claim the throne once I am no more. Lord Arvis... until your son has grown into a man, you shall be his regent. Guide him well to adulthood. I trust you understand... Cough! Cough…

speaker: André
text: I suppose it's our turn... Move out! Carve the terror of the Beige Ritter into the traitors' hearts!

speaker: Byron
text: N-no… No! SIGURD! And to think, I was so close… O gods… Why… Why have you forsaken me…

speaker: Oifey
text: That was quite the fierce bout, sire.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Mm. And to think, none of them were Grannvale's elite! Listen, Oifey, I need to ask something of you.

speaker: Oifey
text: Of course, sire. What is it?

speaker: Sigurd
text: As I recall, the territory of Isaach should be very close to the north-east of Lubeck. From what I've heard, ever since Grannvale won the war, Isaach has been governed by Dannan, Langbalt's eldest son. But I'd wager his influence has yet to reach much of the country's span, so...

speaker: Oifey
text: I beg your pardon, sire?! Are you seriously asking me to abandon you for safety, now of all times? No! I refuse! I will not leave you, sire! I'm here for you no matter what, till I draw my last breath!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Oifey, listen... I know this is a huge imposition, but please. Just hear me out. I... I don't want to lose Seliph. He isn't even two years old yet! I can hardly fight with an infant in tow. Please, Oifey. Take care of Seliph. Take him and find refuge from this blasted war. I know I can trust you, Oifey. You are my only hope.

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire... I... Very well. I'll take Lord Seliph. I'll protect him, no matter what happens. That said, you have to promise me. Promise me that you'll come for us as soon as this war is over. I won't leave you if you can't promise that.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Of course. I swear I'll come for the two of you.

speaker: Oifey
text: Thank you...

speaker: Shannan
text: Hold it! I promised Deirdre that I'll look after Seliph no matter what! I won't hand him over to anyone, not even Oifey, until Deirdre says I can!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Calm down, Shannan... I know you're still hurt about losing Deirdre, but this isn't helping. It's okay. He'll be fine with Oifey.

speaker: Shannan
text: No! I need to protect Seliph! And you're forgetting that the people of Isaach won't exactly be happy to see more Grannvaleans! Oifey alone won't last a minute there, but if I'm there it'll be okay. Who better to protect Seliph in Isaach than the prince of Isaach? Please... I promised her...

speaker: Oifey
text: Now that he mentions it, sire, I would be a tad more at ease if Shannan was there as well. I know you're reluctant to involve one as young as Shannan in something so dangerous. But I think we can agree he's become a talented warrior. Not to mention, I'll need Shannan to secure the people's support.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm... I'm sorry to burden you more, Shannan, but please... Take care of Seliph for me.

speaker: Shannan
text: Okay! Leave it to me! I'm gonna keep getting stronger, and nobody'll ever hurt Seliph! I'll teach him all about Deirdre, but... I wonder how he'll take what happened...

speaker: Oifey
text: I suppose we should get going, then. Farewell, sire. Take care of yourself. I pray victory and clemency find you as soon possible.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Thank you, Oifey. Be careful out there.

speaker: Oifey
text: Yes, sir!

speaker: Sigurd
text: Seliph... I'm so sorry. Please, grow up safe and strong…

speaker: Quan
text: Gentlemen, we've not much further to go. Keep giving it your best. Rumor has it that Sigurd's army should be moving south through the Yied Desert. If we keep this pace north, we should be able to rendezvous with them sooner or later.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Quan, I'm so sorry I dragged you into this. You and your father were too generous sparing so many soldiers to help my brother, even though your father is presently so ill... But are you sure you're both willing to risk crossing a nation as all-powerful as Grannvale? The very thought is terrifying...

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn, you know as well as I that Leonster, a nation built on the legacy of the Crusader Nova, is far stronger than its size suggests. No matter what happens, I could never regret giving my all for a cause as just as Sigurd's. My father feels precisely the same way. There's nothing to worry about, Ethlyn. After all, I'm wielding none other than Gáe Bolg! I'll never fail with it at my side! Sigurd could certainly stand to have my aid.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: I suppose you're right. He'd appreciate any help at this point...

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn, we'll be entering hostile territory very shortly. The enemy could ambush us at any moment, so...

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Actually, Quan... I've been thinking this over quite a bit, and I'm coming with you after all. I'd like to see my brother again, and I simply can't abandon you now.

speaker: Quan
text: I can't allow that! I let you come with me solely because you promised to return home partway. To say nothing of Altena's presence! Look at her, a mere babe of three years curled up aslumber in her mother's lap. Should we be attacked, what then?

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Why, I'd fight my hardest to protect her. Nobody could possibly seize her from me! I certainly never intended at first to take her with us. But she simply wouldn't stop crying when I tried to leave her behind. You're right, though... You're right. I'll take her home.

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn, I'm sorry. I assure you I do know precisely how you feel, but Leif is barely born and waiting for you at home. Our children need their mother. Please, Ethlyn. Return home. I left Finn to defend the capital. You'll be safe with him.

speaker: Ethlyn
text: Very well, but... I'd like just a little more time. I want to stay by your side a little longer. Please, Quan...

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn... Very well. We've a little more time to spare.

speaker: Travant
text: Hehehe... Ah, Quan! The poor sod still has no clue we're tailing him. And there's a woman with him? What a clumsy mistake. Why, I daresay this is the long-awaited end of Leonster's famous Lanceritter! Those hooves'll be sinking clean into the sand. They can't so much as flail at us. Men, close in! This is it! Thracia's destiny lies before us, ripe for the grasping!

speaker: Quan
text: What? Thracian wyvern knights?! No... You cannot be serious! Travant has been at our heels all along! Ethlyn, run! We've no hope of victory in this blasted desert!

speaker: Ethlyn
text: But... What will you do?

speaker: Quan
text: They're like wild hyenas, Ethlyn! Children are little more than easy targets for them! Thracia has sought to reconquer our territory for centuries. I thought my absence would be taken as an invitation, so I left Finn behind with half the army in case they made the obvious move. Not once... Not even once did I ever suspect they would pursue US instead! I... This was all a mistake...

speaker: Ethlyn
text: You can't give up now, Quan! It'll be okay. We're together, aren't we? At the very least, together we'll not go down easily!

speaker: Quan
text: Ethlyn... Forgive me, please…

speaker: Arvis
text: I see. Duke Langbalt fell in battle…

speaker: Reptor
text: A-Arvis! What are we supposed to do now?! It was you who insisted that, even if we left the bulk of our armies on conquests with our sons, Sigurd would pose no threat to me at all! The situation before us is not the outcome you promised me!

speaker: Arvis
text: Reptor, your overreaction is baseless. The deck is still stacked in our favor. The Velthomer army is already lying in wait for the rebels in the Yied Desert's depths. Furthermore, Thracian sellswords should be arriving to reinforce us at any moment. The enemy will assuredly be exhausted. So long as my army and yours cooperate, Sigurd and his rebels ought to fall with ease.

speaker: Reptor
text: I'm holding you to your word this time, Arvis. Remember, I've no objection to you alone claiming the throne once Azmur finally dies. But don't you dare forget your allies…

speaker: Arvis
text: Of course. Must I remind you? The instant the dust of this war settles, House Friege will be granted the Agustrian throne to govern. House Dozel, meanwhile, will be entrusted with the rule of Isaach. Rest assured, Reptor. I will honor your rights to these territories.

speaker: Reptor
text: Hrm... Very well. Then I, too, will fight with all I have…

speaker: Manfroy
text: Kehehehehe... Greetings, Lord Arvis. The plan proceeds precisely on time, I see…

speaker: Arvis
text: Manfroy... If I've told you once, I've told you a thousand times... You must not show your face here. Until the Grannvale throne is mine, I cannot allow you or your brethren to appear in public. Do you not understand?

speaker: Manfroy
text: Oh, we understand. We understand how you indulge the greed of men as vile as Reptor and Langbalt. We understand how even then, you still will not concede the very fact of our existence. The plan was to use those two buffoons until they could be used no further, then cast them aside and use their sons in their stead... Was it not?

speaker: Arvis
text: Mm, but... Hear me well, Manfroy. I refuse to have any part in the revival of your Loptyr Empire. I've no desire to oppress your cult, but I've even less of a desire to consign the world to your dark lord's rule. Remember this well. Yes, the blood of Loptyr's scions flows in my veins, but there is so much more to me than that. My Loptyrian heritage is that of Saint Maira, a man who fought for the rights of the people. And more importantly, I am the one true heir to the Crusader Vala, Loptyr's sworn enemy. I will change this world for the better. Under my rule, humanity shall be free from the pain of prejudice, tyranny and oppression! What a pity it is, that Sigurd must die, but alas, all things require sacrifice.

speaker: Manfroy
text: Ohohoho... A sacrifice for the sake of the Lady Deirdre, you mean. You are terrified, Lord Arvis. You fear her memory may someday return…

speaker: Arvis
text: Don't you dare bring her into this! Need I remind you? We. Are. In. LOVE! Nothing will ever come between us!

speaker: Manfroy
text: Heh heh heh... I suppose you two need to hasten and make proof of this love of yours. Proof that will one day grow up and rise to be a most magnificent king! Heh heh heh…

speaker: Vaha
text: The rebels are finally headed this way? Heh, excellent. Let them walk right into the range of my welcoming gift: Meteor spells! The desert will gladly claim their bodies!

speaker: Travant
text: What's this? The woman was fool enough to have a child with her? Ah, I see... Quan's daughter. Interesting... You there! Tell Quan this: If he doesn't surrender Gáe Bolg, his daughter will meet an untimely end. Heh heh heh... Your move, Quan. Your move.

speaker: Quan
text: N-no! Altena... Ethlyn... So this is where it ends... Travant! You can have Gáe Bolg, but don't you DARE so much as scratch Altena!

speaker: Travant
text: And so ends Quan... Magorn! You're in charge now. Head north and give Sigurd's army a fair share of grief. Let none of them escape. There's a fine bounty on each traitorous head, after all.

speaker: Magorn
text: Yes, Sir! Er, that said, what are we supposed to do with this child? She's just crying and crying. We don't know how to handle this. Shall I put her out of her misery, sir?

speaker: Travant
text: Certainly not. Hand her over to me. She and Gáe Bolg are coming with me back to Thracia.

speaker: Magorn
text: Can't say I expected this, sir. If I may, why exactly are you taking her home with you?

speaker: Travant
text: Moron! You've no need to know! Keep that mouth of yours out of business that isn't yours.

speaker: Magorn
text: Y-yes, sir. I beg your forgiveness, sir. By your leave, sir, we will pursue Sigurd's rebels.

speaker: Travant
text: Good. Don't fail me.

speaker: Travant
text: What’s this? The woman was fool enough to have a child with her? Ah, I see… Quan’s daughter. Interesting. Hand her over to me. Hand her over to me. She and Gáe Bolg are coming with me back to Thracia.

speaker: Magorn
text: Can't say I expected this, sir. If I may, why exactly are you taking her home with you?

speaker: Travant
text: Moron! You've no need to know! Keep that mouth of yours out of business that isn't yours.

speaker: Magorn
text: Y-yes, sir. I beg your forgiveness, sir. By your leave, sir, we will pursue Sigurd's rebels.

speaker: Travant
text: Good. Don't fail me.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Good. We've finally claimed Phinora. The fatherland is finally within our reach. Oifey and Shannan... I pray they and Seliph are faring well...

speaker: Old Man
text: Lord Sigurd, I presume? Welcome to Phinora.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Ah, you must be the local elder. My apologies for dragging even an oasis town like Phinora into this godforsaken war.

speaker: Old Man
text: Mm, at this point it was unavoidable. Actually, we've just received word of yet another skirmish in the desert's southern depths. Alas, we find ourselves in dangerous times...

speaker: Sigurd
text: In the south, you say... What happened there?

speaker: Old Man
text: As we understand it, the lance knights of Leonster were on a march north. They were savaged by Thracian wyvern knights en route. There were no survivors, it seems.

speaker: Sigurd
text: W-what?! You can't be serious!

speaker: Old Man
text: I'm sorry to say I am. By the sound of it, there was a young girl in the Leonster party. Our hearts all break for the poor dear...

speaker: Sigurd
text: That's... that was Ethlyn and Quan... Forgive... forgive me…

speaker: Travant
text: And so ends Quan... Magorn! You're in charge now. Head north and give Sigurd's army a fair share of grief. Let none of them escape. There's a fine bounty on each traitorous head, after all.

speaker: Magorn
text: Yes, Sir! Er, that said, what are we supposed to do with this child? She's just crying and crying. We don't know how to handle this. Shall I put her out of her misery, sir?

speaker: Travant
text: Certainly not. Hand her over to me. She and Gáe Bolg are coming with me back to Thracia.

speaker: Magorn
text: Can't say I expected this, sir. If I may, why exactly are you taking her home with you?

speaker: Travant
text: Moron! You've no need to know! Keep that mouth of yours out of business that isn't yours.

speaker: Magorn
text: Y-yes, sir. I beg your forgiveness, sir. By your leave, sir, we will pursue Sigurd's rebels.

speaker: Travant
text: Good. Don't fail me.

speaker: Aida
text: Lord Reptor, we’re depending upon you.

speaker: Reptor
text: Of course. Even so… I cannot help but wonder if Arvis will honor his word. Perhaps… Perhaps we are nothing more but sacrifices to him.

speaker: Aida
text: Lord Arvis is hard at working making the final adjustments to his Velthomer battle plan. You’ve no need to worry, sire.

speaker: Reptor
text: Very well. I’ll take you at your word, then.

speaker: Aida
text: Now, if you’ll excuse me, sire, I must return to the helm of the Velthomer barricades.

speaker: Aida
text: Heh... He hasn't a clue, has he? Wretched fool…

speaker: Reptor
text: This is it. Until Arvis is ready to move out, this battle is ours and ours alone. Hold to your positions until the enemy stumbles into our range. Do not move otherwise!

speaker: Reptor
text: This is it. The time to strike is upon us! With the fire mages of Velthomer at our side, we shall crush the rebels in one fell swoop!

speaker: Aida
text: Execute the plan. Concentrate all of your fire on Reptor and his army. There will be no survivors under any circumstance. Am I clear?

speaker: Reptor
text: W-what? Velthomer has turned on us?! Argh... So this is what Arvis planned all along…

speaker: Aida
text: Ah, Lord Sigurd. I'm glad to see you're safe.

speaker: Sigurd
text: What's going on? What's caused Velthomer's change of loyalties?

speaker: Aida
text: Lord Arvis has long been aware of your innocence, and was on your side all along. This affair in its entirety was dictated by the whims of Reptor and Langbalt, architects of the conspiracy against you. Lord Arvis was unable to act until now, as the dukes' control of the royal court was simply too powerful to contravene.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Is that so... All's well that ends well, then. I can restore my father's good name in the court, and that'll be the end of it.

speaker: Aida
text: Indeed. Lord Arvis and His Majesty await your return in Belhalla, Lord Sigurd. Please, make your way to the royal city as soon as possible.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Really? Very well. I'll be going, then.

speaker: Aida
text: I hear that Lord Arvis arranged a ceremonial reception for you with the entirety of the Belhalla royal guard. Quite the magnificent celebration of your glorious return is in order today, it seems.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Thank you. After all that's happened the past few years, this ought to be a fitting conclusion. Once we're done I should look into getting my allies some compensation for their help. They certainly deserve it after all this!

speaker: Aida
text: Indeed, sir…

speaker: Arvis
text: Ah, Lord Sigurd. Truly this is quite the auspicious day. Congratulations on your triumphant return to the fatherland!

speaker: Sigurd
text: It's good to see you too, Lord Arvis, and thank you for such a lavish greeting! If I may ask, where is His Majesty?

speaker: Arvis
text: Alas, His Majesty is taken severely ill. He has become permanently bedridden. As such, I am administering all affairs of state on his behalf for the time being.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Is that so? I'm sorry to hear that. I bet my misadventures didn't help His Majesty feel any better! Once we're finished here, I should visit the palace and give him my sincerest apologies.

speaker: Arvis
text: ...I think not.

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hm?

speaker: Arvis
text: Sigurd of Chalphy, I hereby sentence you to death for your crimes of treason. His Majesty will not be seeing you, today or ever.

speaker: Sigurd
text: W-what?! What are you talking about, Lord Arvis?!

speaker: Arvis
text: Heh... You are only realizing now? You are far too naïve, Sigurd. Need I remind you that you and your father still sought to usurp the throne and plotted against the crown? Nothing has changed. It is my duty to exact justice upon you, in the name of my wife, Princess Deirdre. I trust you understand, Sigurd.

speaker: Sigurd
text: P-Princess Deirdre?! That... No, it can't be...

speaker: Arvis
text: Ah, of course. You've never met, correct? Very well. I suppose an introduction would be a fair parting gift before your demise. Come, Deirdre! Greet our guests!

speaker: Arvis
text: Deirdre, allow me to introduce you to Sigurd: the spawn of your father's murderer, Byron. I trust you have some choice words for him?

speaker: Deirdre
text: So... So this is... Sir Sigurd?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre?! No... This can't be happening...

speaker: Deirdre
text: Why... Why are you speaking like this...?

speaker: Sigurd
text: Deirdre! It really is you! No... No, no, no...

speaker: Deirdre
text: Do... Do you know me, sir?

speaker: Sigurd
text: OF COURSE I DO! YOU'RE MY-

speaker: Arvis
text: Enough! Deirdre, stand clear. This is an extremely dangerous man. Rest assured: this traitor will be punished.

speaker: Deirdre
text: But... He... He's... Can't we have even a little more time?

speaker: Arvis
text: Unacceptable. Guards! Escort the princess to the castle!

speaker: Deirdre
text: Wait! Arvis, please! ...Just a little more time…

speaker: Sigurd
text: W-wait! DEIRDRE! Arvis, please! I beg of you! She... She's my...

speaker: Arvis
text: Enough! I grow weary of your ravings. Attention, men! We no longer have any use for keeping the traitors alive. Move in on Sigurd and his party! The time to serve them their punishment has come!

speaker: Sigurd
text: ...D... DAMN YOU, ARVIS!!

speaker: Woman
text: Heard the news? Grannvale's army just swept in and seized Lubeck Castle! Oh... I fear for Silesse's future…

speaker: Young Man
text: To think, Silesse remained such a peaceful place for generations and generations! Argh, how did this world turn into such a savage place…

speaker: Old Man
text: It seems that strengths and abilities are passed down from parents to children. You'll often find that boys'll take up their father's traits more dominantly, while girls'll be more strongly influenced by their mother's.

speaker: Woman
text: That Langbalt's got his thugs going around and clearing out every village they can find! Good thing we somehow kept a little bit of gold hidden away from those brutes! Go on, take it. We know you need it more than us.

speaker: Young Woman
text: Did ya know? The famous Lord Eldigan of Nordion and his wife had themselves a little son before he died a while back. His name's, er... Ares? Something like that. I feel pretty bad for the poor boy... He's gotta be just three or four years old…

speaker: Young Man
text: 'S been a while since Grannvale beat Isaach in the war, but they're strugglin' to put down resistance out in its farthest corners. But the people of Isaach ain't givin' up hope. Prince Shannan's still out there, an' they know someday he'll lead 'em to freedom!

speaker: Man
text: It's terrifying just how far Grannvale has fallen from the peaceful nation it used to be! All they ever do these days is set their army on every country they can get their hands on. Prince Kurth'd be utterly ashamed to know what's become of his beloved Grannvale... You have to do something! I'm begging you... Go to Grannvale! Take the country back from the wicked folk who are perverting all it holds dear!

speaker: Sigurd
text: It can't be... F-Father?! Thank the gods! You're alive!

speaker: Byron
text: Sigurd... What a splendid young man you've become... Cough! C-cough...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Father! Come on, you mustn't give in now!

speaker: Byron
text: No... There's no hope left for me now... Listen well, my son. Langbalt was Prince Kurth's true killer. And Reptor is the one holding his leash... His Majesty must know the truth! I... Death holds no fear for me. But I cannot die in peace not knowing if our honor shall be cleansed of these lies.

speaker: Sigurd
text: It's just as I thought all along... Rest assured, Father. Our good name will be cleared. I promise.

speaker: Byron
text: Sigurd, I... I beg your forgiveness... 'Tis my negligence which condemned you to these torments... Sigurd... Take this. It is Tyrfing... Our exalted blade...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Tyrfing... But, Father! Surely you'll still need this...

speaker: Byron
text: Take it, Sigurd. Use it to... restore our... honor...

speaker: Sigurd
text: F-Father! Hold on... Please! Father...

speaker: Oifey
text: Sire...

speaker: Sigurd
text: Why... Why in the world did he have to... Gah... Reptor! Langbalt! Mark my words! You will pay dearly for all you've done!

speaker: Aideen
text: Is something wrong, Brigid?

speaker: Brigid
text: Oh, Aideen. You heard about what André's been up to lately, right?

speaker: Aideen
text: I did. I've heard of how he murdered our father, and later Mahnya died in Silesse as well... I can barely imagine the evil which would have possessed him to do such monstrous things.

speaker: Brigid
text: ...I'm going to kill André. There's no other way. Whatever the evil is, he has to be stopped. Right here, right now. You get what I'm saying, right, Aideen?

speaker: Aideen
text: Brigid...

speaker: Brigid
text: André's crimes are House Jungby's crimes. They're our crimes, too. They reflect badly on us, even though they really shouldn't. I know I'll have his blood on my hands for the rest of my life, but... Aideen, I want you to understand.

speaker: Aideen
text: Of course I do, Brigid…

speaker: Claude
text: This is the end, Aideen. Our final battle.

speaker: Aideen
text: Indeed.

speaker: Claude
text: I have a little gift for you. Here. Use this to aid our young comrades.

speaker: Aideen
text: This is a Rescue staff, is it not? Thank you, but… why me?

speaker: Claude
text: Well… I’ve yet to speak a word of this to anyone, but as my wife… You should know. Listen well, Aideen. We cannot prevail. This war today will end with our defeat. Everything we hold dear will be lost.

speaker: Aideen
text: ...I beg your pardon?!

speaker: Claude
text: Such is the decree of the gods that I received at the Tower of Bragi. I, too, struggled to accept it at first. However, this is our fate. It is inevitable. I know I am destined to die in this battle. Thus, I entrust you with this staff.

speaker: Aideen
text: That… You must be lying! I cannot believe any of it! I cannot! Please… Please! Tell me this is just a cruel joke…

speaker: Claude
text: Aideen, there is no need to grieve. Our deaths are not the end, but rather a new beginning for us all. Life is fated to fade into death, and with it, so too does mortal form die. And yet, never shall life fade into total nothingness. Death is but the herald for the next step to a perfect state of being. It holds no fear for mankind.

speaker: Aideen
text: But… But, Claude…

speaker: Claude
text: Even as I greet death, a rebirth awaits… Why, look no further than yourself for proof! Within you grows a new life waiting to be born, and I too am a part of it. This, Aideen, is why you must live on.

speaker: Aideen
text: Do… Do you realize what you’re saying, Claude?! Asking me to live on while I accept your death… It isn’t fair…

speaker: Claude
text: Aideen…  I am richly blessed to have known you and been your husband, even so briefly. Please, forgive me…

speaker: Aideen
text: Claude….

speaker: Sigurd
text: Hold on... Ayra?! Why are you still here? Didn't I task you with accompanying Shannan and Oifey to Isaach?

speaker: Ayra
text: You did, but I feel I'd always regret abandoning your army at such a crucial hour. I'm with you until the end, Sigurd.

speaker: Sigurd
